hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַכֹּל מְמִירִין , אֶחָד אֲנָשִׁים וְאֶחָד נָשִׁים. לֹא שֶׁאָדָם רַשַּׁאי לְהָמִיר, אֶלָּא שֶׁאִם הֵמִיר — מוּמָר, וְסוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים.
human_translation: Everyone substitutes both men and women. not that it is permitted for a person to effect substitution; rather, that if one substituted the substitution takes effect, And incurs the forty [ sofeg et ha’arba’im ]
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "One may exchange everything, both men and women. Not that a person is permitted to exchange, but if one exchanged - it is valid, and completes the forty."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא: אָמְרַתְּ ״הַכֹּל מְמִירִין״ — לְכַתְּחִילָּה, וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי ״לֹא שֶׁאָדָם רַשַּׁאי לְהָמִיר אֶלָּא שֶׁאִם הֵמִיר מוּמָר״ — דִּיעֲבַד!
human_translation: notes This itself difficult: You say everyone substitutes ab initio . And then you teach: not that it is permitted for a person to effect substitution; rather, that if one substituted the substitution takes effect, after the fact.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara: Ha ha gufa kashya: Amart 'hakol memirin' - lechatkhilah, vahadar tanei 'lo she'adam rashai lehamir ela she'im hemir mumar' - di'avad!" English translation: "The Gemara: This itself is difficult: You said 'one may exchange everything' - initially, and then it teaches 'only if one exchanged intentionally' - retroactively!"

hebrew_text: וְתִיסְבְּרָא ״הַכֹּל מְמִירִין״ — לְכַתְּחִילָּה? אַדְּקַשְׁיָא לָךְ מִמַּתְנִיתִין, תִּיקְשֵׁי לָךְ קְרָא! דִּכְתִיב ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ וְלֹא יָמִיר אֹתוֹ״.
human_translation: And can you understand Everyone substitutes, ab initio ? before the mishna poses a difficulty for you, the verse should pose a difficulty for you, as it is written: “He shall not alter it, nor substitute it”
llm_translation: "And it was thought, 'Do we say 'everyone is permitted' — initially? A question to you from the Mishnah, a question to you from the verse! For it is written, 'He shall not exchange it, nor shall he substitute it.'"

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: הָכִי קָתָנֵי — הַכֹּל מַתְפִּיסִין בִּתְמוּרָה, אֶחָד אֲנָשִׁים וְאֶחָד נָשִׁים, לֹא שֶׁאָדָם רַשַּׁאי לְהָמִיר, שֶׁאִם הֵמִיר — מוּמָר, וְסוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Yehuda says: This is teaching: Everyone can apply by substitution, both men and women. not that it is permitted for a person to effect substitution, as, if did effect substitution, substitution takes effect and he incurs the forty
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Yehudah said: Thus it was taught — all are eligible for substitution, whether men or women, not that a person is permitted to substitute, for if one does, it is considered a blemish, and he incurs the forty lashes.

hebrew_text: הַכׇּל לְאֵיתוֹיֵי מַאי? לְאֵיתוֹיֵי יוֹרֵשׁ, וּדְלָא כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: What Everyone, to include? to include an inheritor, and not in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: All for the purpose of what? For the purpose of inheritance, but not according to Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: יוֹרֵשׁ סוֹמֵךְ, יוֹרֵשׁ מֵמִיר — דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: יוֹרֵשׁ אֵינוֹ סוֹמֵךְ, וְיוֹרֵשׁ אֵינוֹ מֵמִיר.
human_translation: As we learned An inheritor places hands an inheritor is able to substitute the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: An inheritor does not place hands and an inheritor does not substitute
llm_translation: We have learned in a Mishnah: An heir who leans on a gift, an heir who transfers a gift — these are the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: An heir does not lean on a gift, and an heir does not transfer a gift.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? — יָלֵיף תְּחִילַּת הֶקְדֵּשׁ מִסּוֹף הֶקְדֵּשׁ: מָה סוֹף הֶקְדֵּשׁ — יוֹרֵשׁ אֵינוֹ סוֹמֵךְ, אַף תְּחִילַּת הֶקְדֵּשׁ — יוֹרֵשׁ אֵינוֹ מֵמִיר.
human_translation: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda? He derives the initial consecration from the end of the consecration, Just as the end of a consecrated an inheritor does not place hands so too, the initial consecration, an inheritor does not effect substitution
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda's opinion? — He derives the beginning of the sanctification from the end of the sanctification: Just as the end of the sanctification does not require leaning (support), so too the beginning of the sanctification does not require changing (support).

hebrew_text: וּסְמִיכָה גּוּפַהּ מְנָלַן? תְּלָת ״קׇרְבָּנוֹ״ כְּתִיבִי: חַד — ״קׇרְבָּנוֹ״ וְלֹא קׇרְבַּן גּוֹי, וְחַד — ״קׇרְבָּנוֹ״ וְלֹא קׇרְבַּן חֲבֵירוֹ, וְחַד — ״קׇרְבָּנוֹ״ וְלֹא קׇרְבַּן אָבִיו.
human_translation: And from where do we placing hands itself? “his offering” is written three One his offering but not the offering of a gentile. And one his offering but not the offering of another, And one his offering but not the offering of his father,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And where do we derive the principle of "semikah" itself? Three instances of "korban" are written: one - "korban" and not a non-Jewish offering, one - "korban" and not the offering of another, and one - "korban" and not the offering of his father. English translation:

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי מֵאִיר דְּאָמַר יוֹרֵשׁ סוֹמֵךְ, וְהָכְתִיב ״קׇרְבָּנוֹ״! הַהוּא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְרַבּוֹת כׇּל בַּעֲלֵי חוֹבְרִין לִסְמִיכָה.
human_translation: But according to Rabbi Meir, who said an inheritor places hands isn’t “his offering” written He requires that to include all joint owners [ ba’alei ḥoverin ] in placing hands,
llm_translation: And for Rabbi Meir who said, "An heir can rely," and it is written, "his offering"! That one comes to include all joint debtors for reliance.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, בַּעֲלֵי חוֹבְרִין לִסְמִיכָה לֵית לֵיהּ. מַאי טַעְמָא? דְּהָא לָא מְיַחַד קׇרְבָּן דִּידְהוּ. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לְעוֹלָם אִית לֵיהּ, וְקׇרְבַּן גּוֹי וְקׇרְבַּן חֲבֵירוֹ מֵחַד קְרָא נָפְקָא, דְּאִיַּיתַּר לֵיהּ חַד לְבַעֲלֵי חוֹבְרִין לִסְמִיכָה.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yehuda, he does not accept joint owners placing hands. What is the reason that their offering is not specific And if you wish, say actually, he accepts and he derives the offering of a gentile and the offering of another from one verse, that one remains for him to joint owners in placing hands
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, the authors of the Halachic Midrashim do not have the concept of leaning on the sacrifice. What is the reason? Because it does not unite their own sacrifice. And if you wish, I can say: Indeed, it does have the concept of leaning, and the sacrifice of a gentile and the sacrifice of his fellow Jew are derived from one verse, for one leaning is more appropriate for the authors of the Halachic Midrashim.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר דְּאָמַר יוֹרֵשׁ מֵמִיר, מַאי טַעְמָא? אָמַר לָךְ: ״אִם הָמֵר יָמִיר״ לְרַבּוֹת הַיּוֹרֵשׁ,
human_translation: And what is the reasoning Rabbi Meir, who said an inheritor effect substitution? say to you if he shall at all substitute [ hamer yamir ] to include the inheritor.
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir said: One who inherits from Meir, what is the reason? He said to you: "If the changer changes" to include the inheritor.

hebrew_text: וְיָלֵיף סוֹף הֶקְדֵּשׁ מִתְּחִילַּת הֶקְדֵּשׁ, מָה תְּחִילַּת הֶקְדֵּשׁ יוֹרֵשׁ מֵימִר, אַף סוֹף הֶקְדֵּשׁ יוֹרֵשׁ סוֹמֵךְ.
human_translation: And he derives the end of a consecrated from the initial consecration Just as the initial consecration an inheritor effect substitution, so too, the end of the consecrated an inheritor places hands
llm_translation: And he shall add the end of the consecration from the beginning of the consecration, just as the beginning of the consecration inherits from speech, so too the end of the consecration inherits from proximity.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, הַאי ״וְאִם הָמֵר יָמִיר״ מַאי עָבֵיד לֵיהּ? לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הָאִשָּׁה. וְכִדְתַנְיָא: לְפִי שֶׁכׇּל הָעִנְיָן כּוּלּוֹ אֵינוֹ מְדַבֵּר אֶלָּא לְשׁוֹן זָכָר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ וְלֹא יָמִיר אֹתוֹ״, אִשָּׁה מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְאִם הָמֵר יָמִיר״ לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הָאִשָּׁה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, what does he do with this “And if he shall at all substitute”? to include a woman And as it is taught Since the entire matter speak only in the masculine, as it is stated: “He shall not exchange it, nor substitute it” from where a woman The verse states: “And if he shall at all substitute,” to include a woman.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda: What does the phrase "and if he changes" teach us? To include a woman. And as it was taught: Since the entire matter is speaking only in masculine language, as it is stated: "He shall not exchange it, nor shall he substitute it," how do we know to include a woman? The Talmud teaches us: "And if he changes" to include a woman.

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי מֵאִיר, אִשָּׁה מְנָא לֵיהּ? נָפְקָא לֵיהּ מִ״וְּאִם״. וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, ״וְאִם״ לָא דָּרֵישׁ.
human_translation: And according to Rabbi Meir, from where he a woman He derives it from “And if And Rabbi Yehuda does not interpret “and if”
llm_translation: To Rabbi Meir, does a woman count? It was derived for him from "and." And Rabbi Yehuda does not expound "and."

hebrew_text: וּבֵין רַבִּי מֵאִיר וּבֵין רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי קְרָא לְאִשָּׁה, הָא לָא רַבְּיַיהּ קְרָא — הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: כִּי עָבְדָא תְּמוּרָה לָא לָקְיָא. וְהָאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב, וְכֵן תָּנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: ״אִישׁ אוֹ אִשָּׁה כִּי יַעֲשׂוּ מִכׇּל חַטֹּאת הָאָדָם״ — הִשְׁוָה הַכָּתוּב אִשָּׁה לְאִישׁ לְכׇל עֳונָשִׁין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה!
human_translation: And both Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda, the reason that the verse includes a woman, the verse did not include I would say when performs substitution she is not flogged? But didn’t Rav Yehuda say Rav says, and so too the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught, “When a man or woman shall commit any sin that people commit” the verse equates a woman with a man with regard to all punishments of the Torah?
llm_translation: Between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda, the reason of Rabbi calls to a woman, this is not Rabbi's reason - I would say: When a substitution was made, it was not for the better. And Rav Yehuda said in the name of Rav, and so did the Tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael: "When a man or a woman commits any sin against mankind" - the Scripture equated a woman to a man for all punishments in the Torah!

hebrew_text: אִיצְטְרִיךְ, מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: הָנֵי מִילֵּי עוֹנֶשׁ דְּשָׁוֶה בֵּין בְּיָחִיד בֵּין בְּצִבּוּר, אֲבָל הָכָא, כֵּיוָן דְּעוֹנֶשׁ שֶׁאֵינוֹ שָׁוֶה בַּכֹּל הוּא, דִּתְנַן: אֵין הַצִּבּוּר וְהַשּׁוּתָּפִין עוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה — אִשָּׁה נָמֵי כִּי עָבְדָא לָא לָקְיָא, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: was necessary lest you say this statement a punishment that equally to an individual and to the public. But here, since it is a punishment that does not equally to all, as we learned The public and partners do not render a substitute, a woman as well, when she performs is not flogged. teaches us
llm_translation: It is necessary, what might you say: these matters of punishment that are equal whether for an individual or for a congregation, but here, since a punishment that is not equal for all, as we learned: "The congregation and the partners do not make a substitution" — a woman also, when she performs, does not acquire, it is heard for us.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: קָטָן מַהוּ שֶׁיָּמִיר? הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא בְּקָטָן שֶׁלֹּא הִגִּיעַ לְעוֹנַת נְדָרִים — לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, דְּכֵיוָן אַקְדּוֹשֵׁי לָא אַקְדֵּישׁ, אֲמוֹרֵי מֵמַיר? אֶלָּא כִּי קָמִבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ — בְּקָטָן שֶׁהִגִּיעַ לְעוֹנַת נְדָרִים.
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma: a minor, what is to effect substitution What are the circumstances If we say to a minor who has yet to reach the age of vows, you should not raise the dilemma, as since he cannot consecrate can he effect substitution? Rather, when he raises this dilemma, with regard to a minor who has reached the age of vows.
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ramei bar Ḥama asked: What is the law regarding a minor who makes a vow? How is it comparable? If you say in the case of a minor who has not reached the age of vows - you do not need to ask, for since the holy ones do not sanctify him, why would his words be considered a vow? Rather, when he reaches the age - in the case of a minor who has reached the age of vows.

hebrew_text: מִי אָמְרִינַן, כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר מָר: ״אִישׁ״, מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״כִּי יַפְלִיא נֶדֶר״ — לְרַבּוֹת מוּפְלָא הַסָּמוּךְ לְאִישׁ, דְּקׇדְשׁוֹ קָדוֹשׁ. מִדְּאַקְדּוֹשֵׁי מַקְדֵּישׁ, אֲמוֹרֵי נָמֵי מֵמַיר, אוֹ דִלְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּלָאו בַּר עוּנְשִׁין הוּא, בִּתְמוּרָה לָא מִיתְּפִיס?
human_translation: Do we say since the Master said a man What the verse states Shall clearly utter [ yafli ] a vow, to include a discriminating [ mufla ] on the brink of adulthood, that his consecration takes effect. that he can consecrate he can also effect substitution. Or perhaps, since no is subject to punishments, he cannot apply by substitution,
llm_translation: We say, since Mar said: "a man," what does the Talmud say "when he shall clearly utter his vow" - to include one who is wondrously close to a man, whose sanctity is holy. From those who sanctify, the sanctifiers, the sayers of vows also change, or perhaps: since he is not liable to punishment, is he not apprehended in exchange?

hebrew_text: אִם תִּימְצֵי לוֹמַר קָטָן עָבֵיד תְּמוּרָה, דְּהָא אָתֵי לִכְלַל עֳונָשִׁין, גּוֹי מַהוּ שֶׁיָּמִיר? מִי אָמְרַתְּ מִדְּאַקְדּוֹשֵׁי מַקְדֵּישׁ, דְּתַנְיָא: ״אִישׁ אִישׁ״, מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״אִישׁ אִישׁ״? לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַגּוֹיִם, שֶׁנּוֹדְרִים נְדָרִים וּנְדָבוֹת כְּיִשְׂרָאֵל, אֲמוֹרֵי נָמֵי מֵמַיר. אוֹ דִלְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּלָא אָתֵי לִכְלַל עֳונָשִׁין, כִּי עָבֵיד תְּמוּרָה לָא קָדְשָׁה?
human_translation: if you say a minor can perform substitution, as he will come to subject to punishments, what is a gentile effect substitution? Do you say that his consecration takes effect, as it is taught “Any man [ ish ish ]… What the verse states “ ish ish ”? to include gentiles, that they take vows vow offerings and gift offerings as a Jew he can effect substitution as well. Or perhaps, since he will not come to subject to punishments, when he performs substitution, not consecrated.
llm_translation: If you might say, "A minor can perform a substitution," for he comes to include punishments, what is the law regarding a Gentile who vows? Who said that from the holy ones he sanctifies? As it was taught: "A man, a man," what is the teaching of the verse "a man, a man"? To include the Gentiles, who make vows and freewill offerings like Israelites, the words of the faithful are trustworthy. Or perhaps, since he does not come to include punishments, when he performs a substitution, it is not sanctified?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּתַנְיָא: קׇדְשֵׁי גוֹיִם — לֹא נֶהֱנִין וְלֹא מוֹעֲלִין, וְאֵין חַיָּיבִין עֲלֵיהֶם מִשּׁוּם פִּיגּוּל, נוֹתָר וְטָמֵא, אֵין עוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה, וְאֵין מְבִיאִין עֲלֵיהֶם נְסָכִים, אֲבָל קׇרְבָּנוֹ טָעוּן נְסָכִים, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן.
human_translation: Rava says: Come hear, as it is taught consecrated by gentiles, may not derive benefit but not misuse And them one is not liable for with regard to piggul notar and ritually impure cannot render a substitute And one does not bring libations for but his offering requires libations. the statement of Rabbi Shimon.
llm_translation: Rava said: Come and hear, as it was taught: The offerings of non-Jews - they do not benefit from them, nor are they disqualified, and one is not liable for them due to the prohibition of Pigul. If any remains or becomes impure, they do not make an exchange, and one does not bring libations on them. However, their sacrifice requires libations, the words of Rabbi Shimon.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: בְּכוּלָּן אֲנִי רוֹאֶה לְהַחְמִיר. בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים? בְּקׇדְשֵׁי מִזְבֵּחַ, אֲבָל בְּקׇדְשֵׁי בֶּדֶק הַבַּיִת מוֹעֲלִין בָּהֶן. קָתָנֵי מִיהָא: אֵין עוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה!
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei said: With regard to all of them I see to be stringent. In what is this statement, said? with regard to consecrated for the altar, but with regard to consecrated for Temple maintenance, them misuse In any event, teaches cannot render a substitute
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei said: In all of them, I see to be stringent. In what matters are these words said? In the sanctities of the altar, but in the sanctities of the Temple floor, they are misused. It is taught in a Baraita: We do not make an exchange!

hebrew_text: וְרָמֵי בַּר חָמָא, בְּהִקְדִּישׁ גּוֹי לְהִתְכַּפֵּר גּוֹי — לָא קָמִיבַּעְיָא לִי, כִּי קָמִיבַּעְיָא לִי — בְּהִקְדִּישׁ גּוֹי וּמִתְכַּפֵּר בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל: בָּתַר מַקְדִּישׁ אָזְלִינַן, אוֹ בָּתַר מִתְכַּפֵּר אָזְלִינַן?
human_translation: And Rami bar Ḥama I do not raise a dilemma where a gentile consecrated for a gentile to achieve atonement. When I raise the dilemma, where a gentile consecrated and a Jew achieves atonement do we follow one who consecrated or do we follow the one achieving atonement,
llm_translation: Ramei bar Ḥama said: When one sanctifies a non-Jew in order to atone for a non-Jew - if he did not intend for me, but if he intended for me - when he sanctifies a non-Jew and atones for an Israelite: After sanctifying, do we go, or after atoning do we go?

hebrew_text: תִּיפְשׁוֹט לֵיהּ מִדְּרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הַמַּקְדִּישׁ מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ, וּמִתְכַּפֵּר עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה, וְהַתּוֹרֵם מִשֶּׁלּוֹ
human_translation: Solve this by of Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu said Rabbi Yoḥanan says: one consecrates adds one-fifth But the one achieving atonement can render a substitute And one separates teruma , from his own
llm_translation: They should take it from Rabbi Avahu, for Rabbi Avahu said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: One who consecrates adds a fifth, and one who atones makes an exchange, and the donor gives from his own.

hebrew_text: עַל שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ — טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה שֶׁלּוֹ!
human_translation: for of another, the benefit of discretion is his.
llm_translation: Regarding that which belongs to his fellow - his benefit is good!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָתָם הוּא דְּקָאָתֵי מִכֹּחַ יִשְׂרָאֵל, מִשּׁוּם הָכִי אָזְלִינַן בָּתַר מִתְכַּפֵּר, וְהָוֵה לֵיהּ תְּחִילָּתוֹ וְסוֹפוֹ בְּיַד יִשְׂרָאֵל. אֲבָל הָכָא, הָכִי קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ: מִי בָּעֵינַן מִתְּחִילָּה וְעַד סוֹף דְּתֵיקוּ בִּרְשׁוּת מַאן דְּעָבֵיד תְּמוּרָה? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: say to There, comes on behalf of Jew Due to that we follow one atoning, and initial and its ultimate is in the possession of a Jew, But here, this is how he raises the dilemma: Do we require that from the initial until the ultimate it be in the possession of one who effect substitution shall stand [ teiku ]
llm_translation: He said to him: There, it is when he is standing in the strength of Israel, therefore we go after atonement, and it will have its beginning and its end in the hand of Israel. But here, thus he asks: Do we require from the beginning until the end that it be done with the consent of the one who performs the exchange? This remains undecided.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: מוּקְדְּשֵׁי גּוֹיִם לֹא נֶהֱנִין וְלֹא מוֹעֲלִין. לֹא נֶהֱנִין — מִדְּרַבָּנַן, וְלֹא מוֹעֲלִין — מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא.
human_translation: The Master said consecrated by gentiles, may not derive benefit but not misusing may not benefit by rabbinic law. And he is not misusing by Torah law.
llm_translation: Master said: The consecrated items of Gentiles are neither enjoyed nor benefited from. Not enjoyed - from the Rabbis, and not benefited from - from the Torah.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא? דִּכְתִיב: ״נֶפֶשׁ כִּי תִּמְעֹל מַעַל וְחָטְאָה בִּשְׁגָגָה״, וְיָלְפִינַן ״חֵטְא״ ״חֵטְא״ מִתְּרוּמָה, וּבִתְרוּמָה כְּתִיב: ״בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״, וְלֹא גּוֹיִם.
human_translation: What is the reason As it is written “If anyone commit a trespass, and sin through error, And we derive from “sin” “sin” teruma : And with regard to teruma it is written the children of Israel” But not gentiles.
llm_translation: What is the reason? For it is written: "When a person sins unintentionally and commits a sin inadvertently," and we derive "sin" from "sin" regarding terumah, and concerning terumah it is written: "the children of Israel," and not gentiles.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין חַיָּיבִין עֲלֵיהֶם, מִשּׁוּם פִּיגּוּל, נוֹתָר, וְטָמֵא, דִּכְתִיב בַּהּ בְּטוּמְאָה: ״דַּבֵּר אֶל אַהֲרֹן וְאֶל בָּנָיו וְיִנָּזְרוּ מִקׇּדְשֵׁי בְנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְלֹא יְחַלְּלוּ אֶת שֵׁם וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: And them, one is not liable for with regard to piggul , notar , or ritually impure. as it is written with regard to ritual impurity: “Speak to Aaron and to his sons, that they separate themselves from the holy items of the children of Israel, and that they profane not name”
llm_translation: And not liable upon them, from the matter of Pigul, Notar, and Tamei, as it is written in it in uncleanness: "Speak to Aaron and to his sons, that they separate themselves from the holy things of the children of Israel, and that they do not profane My holy name, etc."

hebrew_text: וְיָלֵיף נוֹתָר ״חִילּוּל״ ״חִילּוּל״ מִטּוּמְאָה, דִּכְתִיב גַּבֵּי טוּמְאָה: ״בְנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְלֹא יְחַלְּלוּוְגוֹ׳״, וּכְתִיב גַּבֵּי נוֹתָר: ״וְאוֹכְלָיו עֲוֹנוֹ יִשָּׂא כִּי אֶת קֹדֶשׁ ה׳ חִלֵּל״.
human_translation: And one derives notar between “profane” “profane” ritual impurity. As it is written with regard to ritual impurity: the children of Israel, and that they profane not And it is written with regard to notar : “But every one that eats it shall bear his iniquity, because he has profaned the holy item of the Lord”
llm_translation: And he shall add the remainder "chilul" "chilul" from tum'ah, as it is written regarding tum'ah: "The children of Israel shall not profane" and it is written regarding the remainder: "And those who eat it shall bear their iniquity, for he has profaned the holy things of the Lord."

hebrew_text: וְיָלֵיף פִּיגּוּל ״עָוֹן״ ״עָוֹן״ מִנּוֹתָר, דִּכְתִיב גַּבֵּי פִּיגּוּל: ״וְהַנֶּפֶשׁ הָאוֹכֶלֶת מִמֶּנּוּ עֲוֹנָהּ תִּשָּׂא״, וּכְתִיב גַּבֵּי נוֹתָר: ״וְאוֹכְלָיו עֲוֹנוֹ יִשָּׂא כִּי אֶת קֹדֶשׁ ה׳ חִלֵּל״, וְכוּלְּהוּ בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְלֹא גּוֹיִם.
human_translation: And derives piggul between “iniquity” “iniquity” notar , as it is written with regard to piggul : “And the soul that eats of it shall bear his iniquity” and it is written with regard to notar : “But everyone that eats it shall bear his iniquity, because he has profaned the holy item of the Lord” And all of them, the children of Israel, but not gentiles.
llm_translation: And he compares Pigul "sin" "sin" from Notar, as it is written regarding Pigul: "And the soul that eats from it shall bear its iniquity," and it is written regarding Notar: "And his iniquity shall the one who eats it bear, for he has profaned the holy of the Lord," and all of them are the children of Israel and not gentiles.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין עוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ וְלֹא יָמִיר״, וּכְתִיב בְּרֵישׁ עִנְיָן: ״דַּבֵּר אֶל בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל לֵאמֹר אִישׁ כִּי יַפְלִיא נֶדֶר בְּעֶרְכְּךָ״.
human_translation: And cannot render a substitute As it is written “He shall not exchange it, nor substitute and it is written at the beginning of the matter: “Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them: When a man shall clearly utter a vow according to your valuation”
llm_translation: And they do not make an exchange, as it is written: "He shall not alter it nor change it," and it is written at the beginning of the matter: "Speak to the children of Israel and say to them: When a man makes a special vow of persons to the Lord according to your valuation."

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא: וְאֵין עוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה, מַאי טַעְמָא? דְּאִיתַּקַּשָׁא תְּמוּרַת בְּהֵמָה לְמַעְשַׂר בְּהֵמָה, וּמַעְשַׂר בְּהֵמָה לְמַעֲשֵׂר דָּגָן. וְגַבֵּי מַעְשַׂר דָּגָן כְּתִיב: ״(כֹּל) [כִּי אֶת] מַעְשַׂר בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אֲשֶׁר יָרִימוּ לַה׳... בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״ — וְלֹא גּוֹיִם.
human_translation: another version And cannot render a substitute What is the reason? that substitution of animals is juxtaposed with the animal tithe and the animal tithe with the grain tithe. And with regard to the grain tithe it is written: “For the tithe of the children of Israel, which they set apart as a gift to the Lord, children of Israel, but not gentiles.
llm_translation: Alternate explanation: And they do not make an exchange, what is the reason? Because the exchange of an animal for tithe of an animal is problematic, and tithe of an animal for tithe of grain. And regarding tithe of grain it is written: "(Every) when the tithe of the children of Israel which they lift up to the Lord... the children of Israel" — and not gentiles.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין מֵבִיא (עֲלֵיהֶן) נְסָכִים, אֲבָל קׇרְבָּנוֹ טָעוּן נְסָכִים, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן. מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״אֶזְרָח״ — אֶזְרָח מֵבִיא נְסָכִים וְאֵין הַגּוֹי מֵבִיא נְסָכִים. יָכוֹל לֹא תְּהֵא עוֹלָתוֹ טְעוּנָה נְסָכִים? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״כָּכָה״.
human_translation: And one does not bring libations but his offering requires libations. the statement of Rabbi Shimon. From where are these matters as the Sages taught homeborn homeborn, brings libations, but a gentile does not bring libations. might burnt offering should not require libations; the verse states: “So
llm_translation: "And one does not bring libations upon them, but his offering requires libations, the words of Rabbi Shimon. From where are these matters derived? For the Rabbis taught: 'A native' - a native brings libations, and a non-Jew does not bring libations. One might have thought that his burnt offering should not require libations? The Talmud teaches us to say, 'Thus.'"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: רוֹאֶה אֲנִי בְּכוּלָּן לְהַחְמִיר. מַאי טַעְמָא? ״לַה׳״ כְּתִיב בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei said: I see in all of to be stringent What is the reason? With regard to it is written: to the Lord
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei said: I see in all of them to be stringent. What is the reason? "To the Lord" is written in it.

hebrew_text: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּקׇדְשֵׁי מִזְבֵּחַ, אֲבָל בְּקׇדְשֵׁי בֶּדֶק הַבַּיִת — מוֹעֲלִין בָּהֶן. מַאי טַעְמָא? דְּכִי גָּמְרִינַן מְעִילָה ״חֵטְא״ ״חֵטְא״ מִתְּרוּמָה, דֻּומְיָא דִּתְרוּמָה (דקדוש) [דִּקְדוֹשָׁה] קְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף, אֲבָל בקדשי בֶּדֶק הַבַּיִת דִּקְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים — לָא.
human_translation: In what is this statement said? with regard to consecrated for the altar, but with regard to consecrated for Temple maintenance, from them misusing What is the reason? that when we learn misuse sin sin from teruma , similar to teruma , which is consecrated inherent sanctity. But with regard to sanctity of the Temple maintenance, whose sanctity value, not
llm_translation: In what case are these matters said? In the sanctities of the altar, but in the sanctities of the Temple floor - they are disqualified. What is the reason? Because when we finish the sin-offering, "sin" is permitted from the terumah, similar to terumah (of holiness) of sanctity the sanctity of the body, but in the sanctities of the Temple floor, the sanctity of blood - no.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה, אָמַר רַב: כׇּל ״לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה״ בַּתּוֹרָה, עָשָׂה (בָּהּ) מַעֲשֶׂה — חַיָּיב, לֹא עָשָׂה (בָּהּ) מַעֲשֶׂה — פָּטוּר.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda says Rav says: any prohibition in the Torah, performed an action it, liable did not perform an action it, exempt
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said, Rav said: Every "you shall not do" in the Torah, if one did the deed - liable, if one did not do the deed - exempt.

hebrew_text: וּכְלָלָא הוּא דְּלָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה פָּטוּר? וַהֲרֵי מֵימֵר, דְּלָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה הוּא, וְלָקֵי, דִּתְנַן: ״לֹא שֶׁהוּא רַשַּׁאי לְהָמִיר, אֶלָּא שֶׁאִם הֵמִיר מוּמָר, וְסוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים״.
human_translation: But is principle that a prohibition that does not involve an action exempt? But there is substitution, which is a prohibition that does not involve an action, and flogged as we learned not that it is permitted for to effect substitution; rather, that if one substituted the substitution takes effect, and incurs the forty
llm_translation: It is a principle that if it does not have an action, one is exempt? And behold it was stated, that if it does not have an action, it is exempt, and it is taught: "Not that he is able to exchange, but if he exchanged intentionally, and incurred the forty."

hebrew_text: אָמַר לְךָ רַב: הָא מַנִּי? רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דְּאָמַר: לָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה — לוֹקִין עָלָיו.
human_translation: Rav said to you: whose is this It is Rabbi Yehuda, who said: a prohibition that does not involve an action, one is flogged for it.
llm_translation: He said to you, Rav: Is this a dispute? It is Rabbi Yehuda, as he said: If it does not involve an action - they flog him.

hebrew_text: וּמִי מָצֵית מוֹקְמַתְּ לְמַתְנִיתִין כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? וְהָא אוֹקֵימְתַּאּ לְרֵישָׁא דְּלָא כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּקָתָנֵי ״הַכֹּל מְמִירִין״, ״הַכֹּל״ לְאֵיתוֹיֵי מַאי? לְאֵיתוֹיֵי יוֹרֵשׁ, וּדְלָא כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה!
human_translation: But can you establish the mishna in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda? But we established the first clause as not in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, as it teaches: Everyone substitutes What everyone to include? to include an inheritor, and not in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda,
llm_translation: And who established the principle for the Mishnah like Rabbi Yehuda? But it was established at the beginning not like Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught: "All are permitted." What does "all" come to include? It comes to include an heir, and not like Rabbi Yehuda!

hebrew_text: הַאי תַּנָּא סָבַר לַהּ כְּוָותֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא — דְּלָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה לוֹקִין עָלָיו, וּפְלִיג עֲלֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא — דְּאִילּוּ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר: יוֹרֵשׁ אֵינוֹ סוֹמֵךְ, יוֹרֵשׁ אֵינוֹ מֵמִיר, וְתַנָּא דִידַן סָבַר: יוֹרֵשׁ סוֹמֵךְ, יוֹרֵשׁ מֵמִיר.
human_translation: tanna this holds in accordance with with regard to one that one is flogged for a prohibition that does not involve an action, and disagrees with him with regard to one as Rabbi Yehuda holds an inheritor does not place hands an inheritor not substitute and the tanna of our holds an inheritor places hands an inheritor substitute
llm_translation: This scholar holds according to his opinion in one matter - that if it does not have an action, they do not flog him, and he disagrees with him in one matter - for even Rabbi Yehuda holds: an heir does not rely on it, an heir does not exchange it, and our Tanna holds: an heir relies on it, an heir exchanges it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אִידִי בַּר אָבִין, אָמַר רַב עַמְרָם, אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי: כׇּל לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה, עָשָׂה בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה — לוֹקֶה, לֹא עָשָׂה בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה — פָּטוּר, חוּץ מִנִּשְׁבָּע, וּמֵימֵר, וּמְקַלֵּל חֲבֵירוֹ בַּשֵּׁם, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא עָשָׂה מַעֲשֶׂה — חַיָּיב. מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא אָמְרוּ: אַף הַמַּקְדִּים תְּרוּמָה לְבִיכּוּרִים.
human_translation: Rav Idi bar Avin says Rav Amram says Rabbi Yitzḥak says Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: every prohibition in the Torah, performed an action it, flogged. did not perform an action it, exempt except for one who takes an oath, and one who effects substitution, and one who curses another using the name even though he did not perform an action, liable They said in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: Also one who teruma prior to first fruits
llm_translation: Rav Idi bar Avin said, Rav Amram said, Rabbi Yitzchak said, Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean: Any negative commandment in the Torah, if one performs the action - he is liable; if he does not perform the action - he is exempt, except for one who swears falsely, or one who makes a vow, or one who curses his fellow using the Name, even though he did not perform the action - he is liable. In the name of Rabbi Yosei the son of Rabbi Chanina they said: Also one who hastens to give terumah to the inspectors.

hebrew_text: נִשְׁבָּע מְנָלַן? אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי מֵאִיר: אָמַר קְרָא ״כִּי לֹא יְנַקֶּה ה׳ אֵת אֲשֶׁר יִשָּׂא אֶת שְׁמוֹ לַשָּׁוְא״, בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל מַעְלָה
human_translation: From where do we one who takes an oath Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Meir the verse states: “For the Lord will not hold him guiltless that takes His name in vain” The higher, court
llm_translation: Sworn from where? Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Meir: The verse says, "For the Lord will not hold him guiltless that takes His name in vain." The Heavenly Court.

hebrew_text: אֵין מְנַקִּין אוֹתוֹ, אֲבָל בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל מַטָּה מַלְקִין אוֹתוֹ וּמְנַקִּין אוֹתוֹ.
human_translation: does not hold him guiltless, but the lower, court flogs him, and absolves him
llm_translation: One does not administer lashes to him, but the court of the tribe administers lashes to him and administers him.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְאַבָּיֵי: וְאֵימָא לָא תִּיהְוֵי לֵיהּ נְקִיּוּת כְּלָל! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִם כֵּן, לִכְתּוֹב קְרָא ״לֹא יִנָּקֶה״ וְלִישְׁתּוֹק, ״ה׳״ לְמָה לִי? בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל מַעְלָה הוּא דְּאֵין מְנַקִּין אוֹתוֹ, אֲבָל בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל מַטָּה מַלְקִין וּמְנַקִּין אוֹתוֹ.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said to Abaye: But say he cannot be absolved at all? said to him: If so, let the verse write “Will not hold him guiltless,” and be silent. Why do I the Lord it is the higher court that will not hold him guiltless, but the lower court flogs and absolves him
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Papa to Abbaye: And why not let him be completely clean? He said to him: If so, let it be written in the verse "he shall not be acquitted" and be silent, why do I need the name of God? It is the heavenly court that does not acquit him, but the earthly court lashes and acquits him.

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן שְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא, שְׁבוּעַת שֶׁקֶר מְנָלַן? רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דִּידֵיהּ אָמַר: ״לַשָּׁוְא״ ״לַשָּׁוְא״ שְׁנֵי פְּעָמִים, אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לִשְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא — תְּנֵיהוּ עִנְיָן לִשְׁבוּעַת שֶׁקֶר, דְּלוֹקֶה.
human_translation: We found an oath in vain From where do we a false oath? Rabbi Yoḥanan himself says “In vain…in vain,” twice If is not matter of an oath in vain, apply it matter of a false oath, that is flogged.
llm_translation: We found an oath of falsehood, from where is an oath of falsehood derived? Rabbi Yochanan said: "To falsehood," "to falsehood" twice, if it is not relevant to an oath of falsehood - attribute it to an oath of lies, for it is fitting.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: שְׁבוּעַת שֶׁקֶר הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִי נֵימָא דַּאֲמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ וַאֲכַל — הָתָם (הוּא) מַעֲשֵׂה עֲבַד, וְאֶלָּא דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁאוֹכַל״ וְלָא אֲכַל — הָהוּא מִי לָקֵי? וְהָאִיתְּמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאוֹכַל כִּכָּר זֶה הַיּוֹם״ וְעָבַר הַיּוֹם וְלֹא אָכַל — רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ אָמְרִי: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu objects to this What are the circumstances false oath If we say that said: that I will not eat and he ate there he performed an action And rather where he said: that I will eat and he did not eat is that flogged? But wasn’t it stated: an oath that I will eat this loaf today, and the day passed and he had not eaten Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish say: He is not flogged.
llm_translation: Rebbe Avahu objects to this: How is the oath of a false claim valued? If it is said that he declared, "I will not eat," and then he ate - there, it is a case of a completed action. But if he said, "I will eat," and did not eat - who is liable in that case? And it was stated: "An oath that I will eat this loaf today," and the day passed and he did not eat - Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: He is not liable.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה, דְּלָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה הוּא, וְכׇל לָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה אֵין לוֹקִין עָלָיו. וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה, מִשּׁוּם דְּהָוֵה לֵיהּ הַתְרָאַת סָפֵק, וְכׇל הַתְרָאַת סָפֵק אֵין לוֹקִין עָלָיו!
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan says he is not flogged, as it is a prohibition that does not involve an action, and one is not flogged for any prohibition that does not involve an action. And Reish Lakish says he is not flogged, as an uncertain forewarning for and one is not flogged for any an uncertain forewarning.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan says: He is not liable, because it does not involve an action, and for every prohibition that does not involve an action, one is not liable. And Reish Lakish says: He is not liable, because it involves a doubtful warning, and for every doubtful warning, one is not liable!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: תְּהֵא בְּ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״.
human_translation: Rather, Rabbi Abbahu says: Let be where I ate or I did not eat
llm_translation: Rather, Rabbi Avahu said: Let it be in "I have eaten" and "I have not eaten."

hebrew_text: וּמַאי שְׁנָא דְּקָא מְרַבֵּה ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ מֵ״אוֹכַל״ וְלֹא אָכַל? אָמַר רָבָא: בְּפֵירוּשׁ רִיבְּתָה תּוֹרָה שֶׁקֶר דּוֹמֶה לְשָׁוְא, מָה שָׁוְא לְשֶׁעָבַר, אַף שֶׁקֶר לְשֶׁעָבַר.
human_translation: And what is different that includes I ate, or: I did not eat, than I will eat, and did not eat? Rava says: The Torah explicitly includes a false similar to in vain: Just as in vain to the past, so too, false to the past.
llm_translation: And what is the difference that it says "I have eaten" and "I have not eaten" from "I will eat" and have not eaten? Rava said: In the explanation, the Torah's falsehood is similar to emptiness, just as emptiness for the past, so too falsehood for the past.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה לְרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל כִּכָּר זוֹ״, ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכְלֶנָּה״, ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכְלֶנָּה״, וַאֲכָלָהּ — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. וְזוֹהִי שְׁבוּעַת בִּיטּוּי, שֶׁחַיָּיבִין עַל זְדוֹנָהּ מַכּוֹת, וְעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ קׇרְבָּן עוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד. זוֹהִי לְמַעוֹטֵי מַאי? לָאו לְמַעוֹטֵי ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְלֹא ״אָכַלְתִּי״, דְּלָא לָקֵי?
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya raised an objection to Rabbi Abbahu an oath that I will not eat this loaf; an oath that I will not eat it; an oath that I will not eat it, and he ate it, he is liable only one And this is oath of an utterance for which one is liable lashes for its intentional and a sliding-scale offering for its unwitting This is what to exclude? not to exclude I ate or: I did not eat that not flogged
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him, Rabbi Yirmeya to Rabbi Avahu: "An oath not to eat this loaf," "an oath not to eat it," "an oath not to eat it," and he ate it - he is only liable for one. And this is the oath of clarification, for which one is liable for intentional violation with lashes, and for unintentional violation with a guilt-offering that ascends and descends. What is this coming to exclude? Is it not coming to exclude "I ate" and not "I did not eat," for it is not established?

hebrew_text: לֹא, זוֹ הִיא דְּעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ מַיְיתֵי קׇרְבָּן, אֲבָל ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ לָא מַיְיתֵי קׇרְבָּן. וּמַנִּי? רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל הִיא, דְּאָמַר: אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא עַל הֶעָתִיד לָבֹא, אֲבָל מִילְקָא לָקֵי.
human_translation: No, This is for which brings an offering for its unwitting but I ate or: I did not he does not bring an offering. And whose It is Rabbi Yishmael, who said: liable only for the future, but flogged
llm_translation: Not, this is that on its inadvertent sin brings a sacrifice, but "I ate" and "I did not eat" does not bring a sacrifice. And from where do we know this? Rabbi Yishmael said: One is only liable for what is destined to come, but not for what has already passed.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: זוֹהִי שְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא שֶׁחַיָּיבִין עַל זְדוֹנָהּ מַכּוֹת, וְעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ פָּטוּר. ״זוֹהִי״ לְמַעוֹטֵי מַאי? לָאו לְמַעוֹטֵי ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״, דְּלָא לָקֵי?
human_translation: say the latter clause this is oath in vain, for which one is liable lashes it intentionally and for one is exempt it unwittingly. What This is to exclude? not to exclude I ate or: I did not eat that he is not flogged
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: Zohi shevu'at shavua shechayavin al zedonah makot, ve'al shigagatah patur. 'Zohi' lema'utei mai? Lavo lema'utei 'akhalti' ve'lo akhalti, de'la lo laki?" English translation: "The reason for this is the oath of falsehood for which one is liable for intentional transgression, but exempt for unintentional transgression. 'This' - to exclude what? Not to exclude 'I ate' and 'I did not eat,' for it does not come into play."

hebrew_text: לֹא, זוֹהִי דְּעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ פָּטוּר מִקׇּרְבָּן, אֲבָל ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ — מַיְיתֵי קׇרְבָּן. וּמַנִּי? רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הִיא, דְּאָמַר: מְבִיאִין קׇרְבָּן לְשֶׁעָבַר.
human_translation: No, This is for which one is exempt from an offering it unwittingly, but I ate or: I did not eat he brings an offering. And whose It is Rabbi Akiva, who said: One brings an offering for the past.
llm_translation: Not, this is that on its inadvertent act exempt from offering, but "I ate" and "I did not eat" — brings offering. And from where? Rabbi Akiva it is, who said: One brings offering for a past act.

hebrew_text: וְהָא אָמְרַתְּ רֵישָׁא רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל! אֶלָּא, מִדְּסֵיפָא רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא — רֵישָׁא נָמֵי רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, וְרֵישָׁא לָאו לְמַעוֹטֵי ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״, אֶלָּא לְמַעוֹטֵי ״אוֹכַל״ וְלֹא אָכַל.
human_translation: But didn’t you say the first clause Rabbi Yishmael, Rather, that the latter clause Rabbi Akiva, the first clause Rabbi Akiva as well. And the first clause. not, to exclude I ate or: I did not eat Rather, to exclude I will eat and he did not eat
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "And did you not say, Rabbi Yishmael, at the beginning? Rather, from the end, Rabbi Akiva said - at the beginning, it is said by Rabbi Akiva, and at the beginning, not to exclude 'I ate' and 'I did not eat,' but to exclude 'eating' and not eating."

hebrew_text: וּמַאי שְׁנָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּקָאֵי בִּלְהַבָּא — מְמַעֵט לְהַבָּא, קָאֵי בִּלְהַבָּא — מְמַעֵט לְשֶׁעָבַר?
human_translation: And what is different Since deals with the future, exclude the future. deals with the future, exclude the past?
llm_translation: And what is the difference? Because it stands in the flame - if it diminishes the flame, it stands in the flame - if it diminishes the crossing?

hebrew_text: וּמֵימֵר. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְתַנָּא: לָא תִּתְנִי ״וּמֵימֵר״, מִשּׁוּם דִּבְדִיבּוּרוֹ עָשָׂה מַעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: And one who effects substitution. Rabbi Yoḥanan said to the tanna Do not teach: And one who effects substitution, because performs an action by his speech.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And Meimar. Rabbi Yochanan said to the Tanna: Do not teach "and Meimar," because his speech constituted an action.

hebrew_text: הַמְקַלֵּל אֶת חֲבֵירוֹ בַּשֵּׁם. מְנָלַן? אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, אָמַר רַבִּי אוֹשַׁעְיָא: אָמַר קְרָא ״אִם לֹא תִשְׁמֹר״, וּכְתִיב ״וְהִפְלָא ה׳ אֶת מַכּוֹתְךָ״. הַפְלָאָה זוֹ אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ מַהוּ, כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר ״וְהִפִּילוֹ הַשּׁוֹפֵט וְהִכָּהוּ לְפָנָיו״ — הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר: הַפְלָאָה זוֹ מַלְקוֹת.
human_translation: one who curses another using the name From where do we Rabbi Elazar says Rabbi Oshaya says: The verse states: “If you will not observe And it is written “Then the Lord will make your plagues wondrous [ vehifla ]” this hafla’a , I do not know what its is. When it says: “And the judge shall cause him to lie down [ vehippilo ] and to be beaten before him” you must say hafla’a is lashes.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: One who curses his fellow by the Name. Whence do we derive this? Rabbi Elazar said, Rabbi Oshaya said: The verse says, "If you do not heed," and it is written, "Then Hashem will make extraordinary your blows." This extraordinary thing I do not know what it is, but when it says, "And the judge shall cast him down and strike him before him," - you should say: this extraordinary thing is lashes.

hebrew_text: אֵימַר: אֲפִילּוּ שְׁבוּעַת אֱמֶת? בְּהֶדְיָא כְּתִיב: ״שְׁבוּעַת ה׳ תִּהְיֶה בֵּין שְׁנֵיהֶם״.
human_translation: say even a true oath It is written explicitly “The oath of the Lord shall be between them both,
llm_translation: Statement: Even an oath of truth? For it is written: "The oath of the Lord shall be between them."

hebrew_text: אֵימַר הָנֵי מִילֵּי לְפַיֵּיס אֶת חֲבֵירוֹ, אֲבָל מִילְקָא לִילְקֵי? לָא מָצֵית אָמְרַתְּ, דְּהָכְתִיב ״וּבִשְׁמוֹ תִּשָּׁבֵעַ״.
human_translation: say this statement to appease the other, but should be flogged? You cannot say as it is written: and by His name you shall swear”
llm_translation: Statement: These words to appease his fellow, but words to quarrel? Not found you said, as it is written "and in His name you shall swear."

hebrew_text: הָהוּא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְרַב, דְּאָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב: מִנַּיִן שֶׁנִּשְׁבָּעִין לְקַיֵּים אֶת הַמִּצְוֹת? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״נִשְׁבַּעְתִּי וָאֲקַיֵּמָה לִשְׁמוֹר מִשְׁפְּטֵי צִדְקֶךָ״. הָכְתִיב קְרָא אַחֲרִינָא: ״וּבוֹ תִדְבָּק וּבִשְׁמוֹ תִּשָּׁבֵעַ״.
human_translation: that required for of Rav? As Rav Giddel said Rav said: From where that take an oath to fulfill the mitzvot? as it is stated: “I have sworn, and have confirmed it, to observe Your righteous ordinances” Isn’t another verse written: and to Him you shall cleave, and by His name you shall swear”
llm_translation: That one asked him according to Rav, for Rav Giddel said in the name of Rav: From where do we derive that one must swear to fulfill the commandments? As it is stated: "I have sworn and I will fulfill it, to observe Your righteous ordinances." Another verse is written: "And by His name one shall swear."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְמַאי אֲתָא — לִמְקַלֵּל אֶת חֲבֵירוֹ בַּשֵּׁם. וְאֵימָא — לְמוֹצִיא שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם לְבַטָּלָה? מִי גָּרַע מְקַלֵּל אֶת חֲבֵירוֹ בַּשֵּׁם מִמּוֹצִיא שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם לְבַטָּלָה?
human_translation: Rather, comes to what? to one who curses another using the name But say to one who pronounces the name of Heaven in vain? is cursing another using the name less than pronouncing the name of Heaven in vain?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rather, for what purpose does he come? — To curse his fellow in the name. But why? — To utter the name of Heaven for nullification? Who is more severe, one who curses his fellow in the name or one who utters the name of Heaven for nullification?

hebrew_text: אֲנַן, הָכִי קָא קַשְׁיָא לַן: אֵימָא מוֹצִיא שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם לְבַטָּלָה — תִּיסְגֵּי לֵיהּ בְּמַלְקוֹת, אֲבָל מְקַלֵּל חֲבֵירוֹ בַּשֵּׁם, כֵּיוָן דְּקָעָבֵיד תַּרְתֵּי, דְּקָא מַפֵּיק שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם לְבַטָּלָה וְקָמְצַעַר לֵיהּ לְחַבְרֵיהּ — לָא תִּיסְגֵּי לֵיהּ בְּמַלְקוֹת!
human_translation: This is what is difficult for us: say for one who pronounces the name of Heaven in vain, it is sufficient for him lashes but one who curses another using the name of God, since he has performed two that he pronounces the name of Heaven in vain, and he inflicts pain on another, it should not be sufficient for him to lashes
llm_translation: We, thus, have a difficulty: say one utters the name of Heaven in vain - let him be punished with lashes, but one who curses his fellow using the name, since he is transgressing two, he is causing the name of Heaven to be nullified and causing distress to his fellow - he shall not be punished with lashes!

hebrew_text: לָא מָצֵית אָמְרַתְּ, דִּכְתִיב ״לֹא תְקַלֵּל חֵרֵשׁ״, וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא לְקַלֵּל אֶת חֲבֵירוֹ — אַזְהַרְתֵּיהּ מֵהָכָא דִּכְתִיב ״לֹא תְקַלֵּל חֵרֵשׁ״, אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ מוֹצִיא שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם לְבַטָּלָה — אַזְהַרְתֵּיהּ מֵהֵיכָא?
human_translation: You cannot say as it is written: “You shall not curse the deaf” Granted, if you say to cursing another, warning for this from here, as it is written: “You shall not curse the deaf.” But if you say pronouncing the name of Heaven in vain, from where is the warning of
llm_translation: I did not find what you said, as it is written "You shall not curse a deaf person," and if you say it is permissible to curse one's fellow - the warning comes from here as it is written "You shall not curse a deaf person." But if you say it is permissible to utter the name of Heaven in vain - where does the warning come from?

hebrew_text: אַלְּמָה לָא? וְהָכְתִיב: ״אֶת ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ תִּירָא וְאֹתוֹ תַעֲבוֹד״! הָהוּא אַזְהָרַת עֲשֵׂה הוּא.
human_translation: Why not, But isn’t it written: “You shall fear the Lord your God, and Him you shall serve” That is a warning a positive mitzva.
llm_translation: "Why not? But it is written: 'You shall fear the Lord your God and Him you shall serve'! That warning is a positive commandment."

hebrew_text: מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא אָמְרוּ: אַף הַמַּקְדִּים תְּרוּמָה לְבִיכּוּרִים. מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא? אָמַר קְרָא: ״מְלֵאָתְךָ וְדִמְעֲךָ לֹא תְאַחֵר״ — ״מְלֵאָה״ אֵלּוּ בִּיכּוּרִים, ״וְדִמְעֲךָ״ אֵלּוּ תְּרוּמָה, וְאָמְרַתְּ ״לֹא תְאַחֵר״.
human_translation: They said in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: Also one who teruma prior to the first fruits What is the reason for Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina? The verse states: “You shall not delay to offer of the fullness of your harvest and the outflow of your presses” The fullness of the harvest, these are first fruits; “And the outflow of your presses,” this is teruma . And says: “You shall not delay,”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: For the sake of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina, they said: Even one who is diligent in giving Terumah to the Bikkurim. What is the reason of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina? It is stated in a verse: "Your fullness and your tears shall not be delayed" - "Your fullness" refers to Bikkurim, "and your tears" refers to Terumah, and it says "shall not be delayed." English translation:

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר: הִקְדִּים תְּרוּמָה לְבִיכּוּרִים, רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא, חַד אָמַר: לוֹקֶה, וְחַד אָמַר: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה. תִּסְתַּיֵּים דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא הוּא דְּאָמַר לוֹקֶה, מִדְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: אַף הַמַּקְדִּים תְּרוּמָה לְבִיכּוּרִים לוֹקֶה.
human_translation: It was stated: teruma prior to the first fruits, Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, One said he is flogged, and one said he is not flogged. It may be concluded that it is Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, who said he is flogged, that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said Also one who teruma prior to the first fruits is flogged.
llm_translation: It was stated: If one precedes the terumah to the Bikurim, Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Yosei the son of Rabbi Chanina, one said: he is liable, and one said: he is not liable. The matter was concluded that Rabbi Yosei the son of Rabbi Chanina is the one who said he is liable, as Rabbi Yosei the son of Rabbi Chanina said: Even one who precedes the terumah to the Bikurim is liable.

hebrew_text: אַדְּרַבָּה, תִּסְתַּיֵּים דְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הוּא דְּאָמַר לוֹקֶה, דִּתְנַן: הָיוּ לְפָנָיו שְׁתֵּי כַּלְכַּלּוֹת שֶׁל טֶבֶל, וְאָמַר: ״מַעֲשֵׂר שֶׁל זוֹ בָּזוֹ״ — הָרִאשׁוֹנָה מְעוּשֶּׂרֶת.
human_translation: On the contrary, it may be concluded that it is Rabbi Elazar who said he is flogged, as we learned If two baskets of untithed produce were before and he said: tithe of this is in that the first tithed.
llm_translation: Ad Ravva, tistayyem d'Rabbi Elazar hu d'amr lokeh, ditnan: hayu l'fanav shtei kalkalot shel tevel, v'amar: "ma'aser shel zo bazo" - harishonah me'usheeret.

hebrew_text: ״שֶׁל זוֹ בָּזוֹ וְשֶׁל זוֹ בָּזוֹ״ — הָרִאשׁוֹנָה מְעוּשֶּׂרֶת, וְהַשְּׁנִיָּה אֵינָהּ מְעוּשֶּׂרֶת. ״מַעַשְׂרוֹתֵיהֶם מַעְשַׂר כַּלְכַּלָּה בַּחֲבֶירְתָּהּ״ — קְרָא אֶת הַשֵּׁם.
human_translation: of this in that and of that in this the first tithed, but the second not tithed. Their tithes tithe, basket in the other, declared the assignation
llm_translation: "Of this one despised and of this one despised" — the first one is tithed, and the second one is not tithed. "Their tithes are a tithe of all produce in its association" — Scripture calls it by name.

hebrew_text: וְאִתְּמַר, רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אָמַר: לוֹקֶה, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהִקְדִּים מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁבָּהּ לְמַעֲשֵׂר רִאשׁוֹן שֶׁבַּחֲבֶירְתָּהּ. תִּסְתַּיֵּים.
human_translation: And it was stated Rabbi Elazar said: He is flogged, because he second tithe of prior to first tithe of the other It may be concluded
llm_translation: And it was stated: Rabbi Elazar said: One is liable to receive lashes, because he gave the second tithe of it to the first tithe of his fellow. The Gemara concludes.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא, דְּאָמַר אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה, לֵימָא קַשְׁיָא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא אַדְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא!
human_translation: But Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, who said he is not flogged. Shall we say Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, a difficulty to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,
llm_translation: Rather, Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Chanina, who said he is not liable, let us say the difficulty of Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Chanina is according to Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Chanina!

hebrew_text: לָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא
human_translation: No, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,
llm_translation: No, Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Chanina.

hebrew_text: אַפְּטוּרָא קָאֵי, וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: לָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה אֵין לוֹקִין עָלָיו. מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא אָמְרוּ: אַף הַמַּקְדִּים תְּרוּמָה לְבִיכּוּרִים.
human_translation: referring to the exemption And this is saying: One is not flogged for a prohibition that does not involve an action They said in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, also one who teruma prior to the first fruits
llm_translation: The apotropaic amulet is standing, and thus he said: If it does not have an action, they do not impose upon it. In the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina, they said: Even one who precedes with a contribution for the Temple treasury.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי שְׁנָא מֵימֵר דְּלָקֵי, מִשּׁוּם דִּבְדִיבּוּרוֹ עָשָׂה מַעֲשֶׂה? מַקְדִּים תְּרוּמָה לְבִיכּוּרִים נָמֵי לִילְקֵי, מִשּׁוּם דִּבְדִיבּוּרוֹ עָשָׂה מַעֲשֶׂה!
human_translation: And what is different one who effects substitution, that he is flogged because he has performed an action with his speech, teruma prior to the first fruits should be flogged as well, because he has performed an action with his speech,
llm_translation: And what is the difference between saying that he kindled the fire because his speech caused an action? He should first separate terumah for the priests and then kindle the fire, because his speech caused an action!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אָבִין: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּלָאו שֶׁנִּיתָּק לַעֲשֵׂה הוּא, דִּכְתִיב: ״מִכֹּל מַעְשְׂרוֹתֵיכֶם תָּרִימוּ״.
human_translation: Rabbi Avin said: It is different there, as it is a prohibition can be rectified by a positive mitzva. as it is written: “Out of all of your tithes you shall set apart
llm_translation: Rabbi Avin said: It is different there, because it is not detached for the purpose of performing it, as it is written: "You shall set aside from all your tithes."

hebrew_text: יָתֵיב רַב דִּימִי וְקָאָמַר לַהּ לְהָא שְׁמַעְתָּא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וְכֹל לָאו שֶׁנִּיתָּק לַעֲשֵׂה לָא לָקֵי?
human_translation: Rav Dimi was sitting and saying this halakha , Abaye said to him: And one is not flogged any prohibition can be rectified by a positive mitzva?
llm_translation: Sitting Rav Dimi and saying to her to that thing you heard, said to him Abbaye: and all not that you disconnected to do not to fulfill?

hebrew_text: וְהָא מֵימֵר, דְּלָאו שֶׁנִּיתָּק לַעֲשֵׂה הוּא, וְלָקֵי, דִּתְנַן: לֹא שֶׁאָדָם רַשַּׁאי לְהָמִיר, אֶלָּא שֶׁאִם הֵמִיר — מוּמָר, וְסוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים.
human_translation: But one who effects substitution, which is a prohibition can be rectified by a positive mitzva, And is flogged, as we learned not that it is permitted for a person to effect substitution; rather, that if one substituted substitution takes effect and incurs the forty
llm_translation: And this is what he said, that if it did not detach for the purpose, and the Tanna teaches: "A person is not permitted to exchange, except if he exchanged - he is considered an expert, and incurs the forty lashes."

hebrew_text: הָוֵי לְהוּ תְּרֵי לָאוֵי וְחַד עֲשֵׂה, וְלָא אָתֵי חַד עֲשֵׂה וְעָקַר תְּרֵי לָאוֵי.
human_translation: There are two prohibitions But one positive mitzva: And one positive mitzva does not come and uproot two prohibitions.
llm_translation: Be to him two negatives and one positive, and not come one positive and uproot two negatives.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי אוֹנֵס, דְּחַד לָאו וְחַד עֲשֵׂה, וְלָא אָתֵי חַד עֲשֵׂה וְעָקַר לָאו, דְּתַנְיָא: אוֹנֵס שֶׁגֵּירַשׁ — אִם יִשְׂרָאֵל הוּא מַחְזִיר וְאֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה, וְאִם כֹּהֵן הוּא לוֹקֶה וְאֵינוֹ מַחְזִיר!
human_translation: But there is rapist As one prohibition: and one positive mitzva: And one positive mitzva does not come and uproot prohibition, as it is taught a rapist who divorced if he is an Israelite, he remarries and he is not flogged. But if he is a priest, he is flogged and he does not remarry
llm_translation: Behold, regarding a case of Ones, where one is a negative commandment and one is a positive commandment, and one does not come to fulfill the positive commandment and annul the negative commandment, as it was taught: If one divorces due to Ones - if he is an Israelite, he must return her and he is not liable to receive lashes, but if he is a Kohen, he receives lashes and does not return her!

hebrew_text: כֹּהֲנִים קָאָמְרַתְּ?! כֹּהֲנִים — טַעְמָא אַחְרִינָא הוּא, דְּרַבִּי רַחֲמָנָא קְדוּשָּׁה יַתִּירָא.
human_translation: You say priests priests is another reason as the Merciful One increased greater holiness.
llm_translation: The priests are saying?! Priests - it is another reason, for Rabbi Rachamana is more holy.

hebrew_text: כְּתַנָּאֵי: ״לֹא יַשְׁאִירוּ מִמֶּנּוּ עַד בֹּקֶר״ — בָּא הַכָּתוּב לִיתֵּן עֲשֵׂה אַחַר לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה, לוֹמַר שֶׁאֵין לוֹקִין עָלָיו, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: subject to tanna’im , you shall let nothing of it remain until the morning, The verse comes to place a positive mitzva after prohibition to say that one is not flogged for it. the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: The Tannaim: "They shall not leave any of it until morning" - the verse comes to give a positive command after a negative one, to say that one is not lashed for it, the words of Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: לֹא מִן הַשֵּׁם הוּא זֶה, אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּהָוֵה לָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה, וְכׇל לָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה — אֵין לוֹקִין עָלָיו. מִכְּלָל דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר לוֹקִין עָלָיו.
human_translation: Rabbi Ya’akov says: is not for reason, rather because it is a prohibition that does not involve an action, and one is not flogged for any prohibition that does not involve an action. By inference, that Rabbi Yehuda holds is flogged for
llm_translation: Rabbi Yaakov says: Not from the name is this, rather because it is not one that has an action, and any that does not have an action - one does not flog upon it. From the principle that Rabbi Yehuda holds one flogs upon it.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יַעֲקֹב, הַאי ״וְהַנֹּתָר מִמֶּנּוּ עַד בֹּקֶר בָּאֵשׁ תִּשְׂרוֹפוּ״ לְמַאי אֲתָא?
human_translation: And Rabbi Ya’akov, for what “but that which remains of it until the morning you shall burn with fire” come?
llm_translation: Rabbi Yaakov said: "And that which remains of it until morning with fire you shall burn" - for what purpose does it come?

hebrew_text: מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לִכְדִתְנַן: הָעֲצָמוֹת, וְהַגִּידִין, וְהַנּוֹתָר — יִשָּׂרְפוּ בְּשִׁשָּׁה עָשָׂר. חָל שִׁשָּׁה עָשָׂר לִהְיוֹת בַּשַּׁבָּת — יִשָּׂרְפוּ בְּשִׁבְעָה עָשָׂר, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין דּוֹחִין לֹא אֶת הַשַּׁבָּת וְלֹא אֶת יוֹם טוֹב.
human_translation: He requires it for that which we learned The bones and the sinews, and the leftover be burned on the sixteenth sixteenth occurs on Shabbat, they be burned on the seventeenth, because them does not override Shabbat or Festival.
llm_translation: He asked him as we learned: the bones, sinews, and leftover parts - should be burned on the sixteenth. If the sixteenth falls on Shabbat - they should be burned on the seventeenth, because we do not postpone either Shabbat or a festival day.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר חִזְקִיָּה, וְכֵן תָּנָא דְּבֵי חִזְקִיָּה: מַאי טַעְמָא? אָמַר קְרָא ״וְהַנּוֹתָר מִמֶּנּוּ עַד בֹּקֶר בָּאֵשׁ תִּשְׂרוֹפוּ״ — בָּא הַכָּתוּב לִיתֵּן בּוֹקֶר שֵׁנִי לִשְׂרֵיפָתוֹ.
human_translation: And Ḥizkiyya says, and so it is taught in the school of Ḥizkiyya: What is the reason The verse states: but that which remains of it until the morning you shall burn with fire.” the verse comes to provide a second morning for burning
llm_translation: And Chizkiyah said, and so too it was taught in the school of Chizkiyah: What is the reason? The verse says, "And that which remains of it until morning you shall burn with fire" — the Scripture comes to give a second morning for its burning.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: כֹּל מִילְּתָא דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא לָא תַּעֲבֵיד, אִם עָבֵיד — מַהֲנֵי, דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ לָא מַהֲנֵי — אַמַּאי לָקֵי? רָבָא אָמַר: לָא מַהֲנֵי מִידֵּי, וְהַאי דְּלָקֵי — מִשּׁוּם דַּעֲבַר אַמֵּימְרָא דְּרַחֲמָנָא הוּא.
human_translation: Abaye said: any matter that the Merciful One states not to perform, if one performed is effective, As, if it enters your mind it is not effective, why flogged Rava said: it is not effective at all. And this that he is flogged: Because he transgressed the statement of the Merciful One.
llm_translation: Abaye said: Any matter that the Merciful One said not to do, if one does it - what is the consequence? For if it is not in your mind, what is the consequence? Why is he liable? Rava said: He is not liable immediately, but this one who is liable - it is because he transgressed the statement of the Merciful One.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: אוֹנֵס שֶׁגֵּירֵשׁ, אִם יִשְׂרָאֵל הוּא — מַחְזִיר וְאֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה, וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ כֵּיוָן דַּעֲבַר אַמֵּימְרָא דְּרַחֲמָנָא לָקֵי, הָא נָמֵי לִילְקֵי! תְּיוּבְתָּא דְרָבָא.
human_translation: raises an objection a rapist who divorced if he is an Israelite, he remarries and he is not flogged. And if you say, since one violates the statement of the Merciful One, he is flogged, this one should be flogged as well a conclusive refutation of Rava.
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: Challenger: If a man compels a woman to divorce, if he is an Israelite - he must return her and is not flogged. But if you say, since the Merciful One has passed a decree, let him also be flogged! The answer is: it is the preference of Rava.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״כׇּל יָמָיו״, כׇּל יָמָיו בַּעֲמוֹד וְהַחְזֵיר.
human_translation: say to you: is different there, as the verse states: all his days” all his days, under arise and remarry
llm_translation: He said to you: It is different there, as the verse says "all his days," all his days with a pillar and a swine.

hebrew_text: וּלְאַבָּיֵי, אִי לָאו דַּאֲמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״כׇּל יָמָיו״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא אִיסּוּרָא הוּא דַּעֲבַד לֵיהּ, אִי בָּעֵי לֶיהְדַּר וְאִי בָּעֵי לָא לֶיהְדַּר, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: And according to Abaye, If the Merciful One did not state “all his days,” I would say he has violated a prohibition if he desires to remarry and if he desires not to remarry teaches us
llm_translation: To Abbaye, if not that the Merciful One said "all his days," I would have said it is a prohibition that one should perform for him, whether he wants to dwell or whether he does not want to dwell, it is implied to us.

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא. מֵיתִיבִי: אוֹנֵס שֶׁגֵּירֵשׁ — אִם יִשְׂרָאֵל הוּא מַחְזִיר וְאֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה, וְאִם כֹּהֵן הוּא לוֹקֶה וְאֵינוֹ מַחְזִיר. קָתָנֵי: ״אִם יִשְׂרָאֵל הוּא מַחְזִיר״ — תְּיוּבְתָּא דְאַבָּיֵי!
human_translation: another version raises an objection a rapist who divorced if he is an Israelite, he remarries and he is not flogged. But if he is a priest, he is flogged and he does not remarry teaches if he is an Israelite he remarries a conclusive refutation of Abaye,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Another teaching. The question was raised: If a rapist who divorces his victim—if he is an Israelite, he must return her ketubah and is not lashed, but if he is a Kohen, he is lashed and does not return the ketubah. It was taught: "If he is an Israelite, he must return her ketubah"—this is the statement of Abbaye!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״כׇּל יָמָיו״, כׇּל יָמָיו בַּ״עֲמוֹד וְהַחְזֵיר״.
human_translation: is different there, as the Merciful One states: all his days” all his days, under arise and remarry
llm_translation: The matter is different there, for the Merciful One said: "All his days," all his days in the standing and returning.

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא אָמַר לָךְ: אִי לָא כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״כׇּל יָמָיו״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: לִילְקֵי וְלֶיהְדַּר, דְּהָוֵה לֵיהּ לָאו גְּרֵידָא, דִּכְתִיב: ״לֹא יוּכַל לְשַׁלְּחָהּ״. אַהָכִי כְּתַב קְרָא ״כׇּל יָמָיו״, לְשַׁוּוֹיֵיהּ לְאוֹנֵס לְלֹא תַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁנִּיתָּק לַעֲשֵׂה, דְּאֵין לוֹקִין עָלָיו.
human_translation: And Rava, say to you if the Merciful One had not stated “all his days,” I would say should be flogged and should remarry for it is solely a prohibition as it is written: He may not send her away. Therefore, the verse writes “all his days,” to render a rapist a prohibition rectified by a positive mitzva, for which one is not flogged.
llm_translation: Rava said to you: If the Merciful One had not written "all his days," I would have said: Let him pluck and adorn, for it is not a prohibition, as it is written: "He may not send her away." But since the verse writes "all his days," it equates it to a case of coercion, where one is exempt from positive commandments, for there is no punishment imposed upon him.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי תּוֹרֵם מִן הָרָעָה עַל הַיָּפָה, דְּרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״מִכׇּל חֶלְבּוֹ״.
human_translation: But there is separates teruma from poor-quality for superior-quality as the Merciful One states: of all the best thereof”
llm_translation: And behold, one separates from the evil onto the beautiful, for the Merciful One said: "From all its fat."

hebrew_text: חֶלְבּוֹ — אִין, גֵּירוּעִין — לָא. וּתְנַן: אֵין תּוֹרְמִין מִן הָרָעָה עַל הַיָּפָה, וְאִם תָּרַם — תְּרוּמָתוֹ תְּרוּמָה. אַלְמָא מַהֲנֵי, תְּיוּבְתָּא דְרָבָא.
human_translation: the best thereof,” yes, not poor-quality And we learned One may not separate teruma from poor-quality for superior-quality and if one did separate teruma his teruma is teruma . Apparently, is effective, a conclusive refutation of Rava.
llm_translation: Chelevo - ein, geiruin - la. U'tenan: ein tormin min hara'ah al hayafah, ve'im taram - terumatoh terumah. Alma mahanei, teyuveta d'Rava.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ רָבָא: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, כְּרַבִּי אִילְעָא, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא: מִנַּיִן לְתוֹרֵם מִן הָרָעָה עַל הַיָּפָה שֶׁתְּרוּמָתוֹ תְּרוּמָה? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא תִשְׂאוּ עָלָיו חֵטְא בַּהֲרִימְכֶם אֶת חֶלְבּוֹ מִמֶּנּוּ״. אִם אֵינוֹ קָדוֹשׁ, נְשִׂיאוּת חֵטְא לָמָּה? מִיכָּן לַתּוֹרֵם מִן הָרָעָה עַל הַיָּפָה שֶׁתְּרוּמָתוֹ תְּרוּמָה.
human_translation: Rava say to you: It is different there, in accordance with Rabbi Ile’a. As Rabbi Ile’a said: From where with regard to one who separates teruma from poor-quality for superior-quality that his teruma is teruma ? As it is stated “And you shall bear no sin by reason of it, seeing that you have set apart from it the best thereof” if it is not consecrated why bear a sin From here with regard to one who separates teruma from poor-quality for superior-quality that his teruma is teruma .
llm_translation: Rava said to you: It is different there, like Rabbi Ilai, for Rabbi Ilai said: From where do we derive that one should separate from the evil for the good, so that his separation is a true separation? As it is stated: "And you shall not bear sin because of it when you have lifted up the best of it." If it is not holy, why should lifting it up be a sin? From here we learn that one should separate from the evil for the good, so that his separation is a true separation.

hebrew_text: וּלְאַבָּיֵי, אִי לָאו דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״וְלֹא תִשְׂאוּ עָלָיו חֵטְא״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא הָכִי אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: עֲבֵיד מִצְוָה מִן הַמּוּבְחָר, וְאִי לָא עָבֵיד — ״חוֹטֵא״ לָא מִיקְּרֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: And according to Abaye, If the Merciful One had not stated: “And you shall bear no sin by reason of it,” I would say this is what the Merciful One said: Perform the mitzva in the optimal but if one did not perform he is not called a sinner. teaches us
llm_translation: To Abbaye, if not that the Merciful One said "and you shall not bear sin because of him," I would have said thus: The Merciful One said: Perform a commandment with a chosen one, and if not, it is not called "sin," as it is implied to us.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי מִמִּין עַל שֶׁאֵינוֹ מִינוֹ, דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״כׇּל חֵלֶב יִצְהָר״, לִיתֵּן חֵלֶב לָזֶה וְחֵלֶב לָזֶה, וּתְנַן: אֵין תּוֹרְמִין מִמִּין עַל שֶׁאֵינוֹ מִינוֹ, וְאִם תָּרַם — אֵין תְּרוּמָתוֹ תְּרוּמָה, אַלְמָא לָא מַהֲנֵי, תְּיוּבְתָּא דְאַבָּיֵי.
human_translation: But isn’t there from type to another type as the Merciful One states: “All the best of the oil, to give the best of one and the best of another And we learned One may not separate teruma from type for another type, and if one did separate teruma his teruma is not teruma . Apparently, is not effective. a conclusive refutation of Abaye.
llm_translation: Behold, from a different species onto that which is not its species, as the Merciful One said, "All fat is the Lord's," to give fat to this one and fat to that one. And we learned: One does not separate terumah from a different species onto that which is not its species, and if one separated — his terumah is not considered terumah. This implies that it is not effective, a refutation of Abbaye's statement.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ אַבַּיֵּי: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״רֵאשִׁיתָם״ — רֵאשִׁית לָזֶה וְרֵאשִׁית לָזֶה. וְכֵן אָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא: ״רֵאשִׁית״.
human_translation: Abaye say to you: is different there, as the verse states: “The first part of them,” a first part for this and a first part for that And Rabbi Ile’a likewise says “the first part
llm_translation: He said to you Abaye: It is different there, as the verse says "their beginning" - a beginning for this and a beginning for that. And so said Rabbi Ilai: "beginning."

hebrew_text: וּלְרָבָא, אִי לָאו דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״רֵאשִׁית״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא תִּירוֹשׁ וְיִצְהָר, דִּכְתִיב בְּהוּ ״חֵלֶב״ ״חֵלֶב״, דְּאֵין תּוֹרְמִין מִזֶּה עַל זֶה.
human_translation: And according to Rava, If the Merciful One had not stated: “The first part I would say wine and oil, with regard to which it is written: “Best…best,” that one may not separate teruma from this for that
llm_translation: And for Rava, if not for what the Merciful One said "reshit," I would have said grape juice and olive oil, as it is written with them "chelev" "chelev," that one does not tithe from one upon the other.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל תִּירוֹשׁ וְדָגָן, דָּגָן וְדָגָן, דְּחַד ״חֵלֶב״ כְּתִיב בְּהוּ, כִּי תָרֵים מֵהַאי אַהַאי — לָא לָקֵי. כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״רֵאשִׁית״, לִיתֵּן חֵלֶב לָזֶה וְחֵלֶב לָזֶה.
human_translation: But wine and grain, grain and grain, with regard to which “best” is written once, when one separates teruma from this for that he is not flogged. the Merciful One writes: “The first part give the best of this and the best of that.
llm_translation: But wine and grain, grain and grain, one "chelev" is written in it, when you mix from this with that - it does not take effect. The Merciful One wrote "reshit," to give fat to this one and fat to that one.

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא, הָא תִּירוֹשׁ וְדָגָן, דְּחַד ״חֵלֶב״ כְּתִיב בְּהוּ — תָּרֵים מֵהַאי אַהַאי. כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״רֵאשִׁית״.
human_translation: another version wine and grain, with regard to which “best” is written once, one may separate teruma from this for that the Merciful One writes: “The first part
llm_translation: The other opinion, this wine and grain, because it is written "fat" in one of them - you should separate from this to that. The Merciful One wrote "first."

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי חֲרָמִים, דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: ״לֹא יִמָּכֵר וְלֹא יִגָּאֵל״, וּתְנַן: חֶרְמֵי כֹהֲנִים אֵין פּוֹדִין אוֹתָם, אֶלָּא נוֹתְנָין לַכֹּהֵן. אַלְמָא לָא מַהֲנֵי, תְּיוּבְתָּא דְאַבָּיֵי.
human_translation: But there is dedications which the Merciful One states: “No shall be sold or redeemed; And we learned Items dedicated to priests are not redeemed; rather, one gives them to the priest. Apparently, is not effective. a conclusive refutation of Abaye.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And behold, there are cherem, as the Merciful One said: "He shall not sell it, nor redeem it," and we learned: The cherem of the priests are not redeemed, but are given to the priest. This implies that it is not beneficial, the statement of Abbaye.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״קֹדֶשׁ קָדָשִׁים הוּא״ — בַּהֲוָויָיתוֹ יְהֵא.
human_translation: say to you: It is different there, as the Merciful One states: “Is most holy,” it shall be as it is.
llm_translation: He said to you: It is different there, as the Merciful One said, "He is holy of holies" - in his existence he shall be.

hebrew_text: וּלְרָבָא, הַאי ״הוּא״ לְמַעוֹטֵי בְּכוֹר, דְּתַנְיָא: בִּבְכוֹר נֶאֱמַר ״לֹא תִפְדֶּה״ וְנִמְכָּר הוּא, בְּמַעֲשֵׂר נֶאֱמַר ״לֹא יִגָּאֵל״ וְאֵינוֹ נִמְכָּר, לֹא חַי וְלֹא שָׁחוּט, לא תָּם וְלֹא בַּעַל מוּם.
human_translation: And according to Rava, this “Is to exclude a firstborn As it is taught It is stated with regard to a firstborn you shall not redeem; But it sold. it is stated with regard to tithe “It shall not be redeemed” and not be sold, not alive and not slaughtered, not unblemished and not blemished.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And for Rava, this "he" is to exclude the firstborn, as it was taught: In the case of a firstborn, it says "it shall not be redeemed," and it can be sold. In the case of tithe, it says "it shall not be redeemed," and it cannot be sold, neither alive nor slaughtered, neither whole nor blemished.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי תְּמוּרָה, דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ וְלֹא יָמִיר אוֹתוֹ״, וְתָנָא: לֹא שֶׁאָדָם רַשַּׁאי לְהָמִיר, אֶלָּא שֶׁאִם הֵמִיר — מוּמָר, וְסוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים. אַלְמָא מַהֲנֵי, תְּיוּבְתָּא דְרָבָא!
human_translation: But isn’t there substitution, which the Merciful One states: “He shall not exchange it, nor substitute it” and it is taught not that it is permitted for a person to effect substitution; rather, that if one substituted the substitution takes effect, and incurs the forty Apparently, is effective, a conclusive refutation of Rava.
llm_translation: Behold the exchange, as the Merciful One said: "He shall not exchange it, nor shall he substitute it." And it was taught: Not that a person is able to exchange, but rather if he did exchange — he is deemed a transgressor, and incurs the forty lashes. This implies, the rebuttal of Rava!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״וְהָיָה הוּא וּתְמוּרָתוֹ יִהְיֶה קֹּדֶשׁ״.
human_translation: say to you: It is different there, as verse states: both it and that for which it is substituted shall be holy,”
llm_translation: He said to you: It is different there, as the verse says, "And it shall be he and his substitute shall be holy."

hebrew_text: וּלְאַבָּיֵי, אִי לָאו דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״וְהָיָה הוּא וּתְמוּרָתוֹ״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא תֵּצֵא זוֹ וְתִכָּנֵס זוֹ, קָמַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: And according to Abaye, if the Merciful One had not stated: “Both it and that for which it is substituted I would say this will leave and that will enter teaches us
llm_translation: To Abbaye, if not that which the Merciful One said "and it shall be he and his substitute," I would say let this one go out and let that one come in, it teaches us.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי בְּכוֹר, דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״לֹא תִפְדֶּה״, וּתְנַן: יֵשׁ לָהֶן פִּדְיוֹן, וְלִתְמוּרוֹתֵיהֶן פִּדְיוֹן, חוּץ מִן הַבְּכוֹר וּמִן הַמַּעֲשֵׂר, אַלְמָא לָא מַהֲנֵי, תְּיוּבְתָּא דְאַבָּיֵי.
human_translation: But isn’t there a firstborn which the Merciful One states: you shall not redeem; And we learned are subject to redemption and their substitutes to redemption except for the firstborn and the tithe Apparently, is not effective, a conclusive refutation of Abaye.
llm_translation: Behold, regarding the firstborn, as the Merciful One said "you shall not redeem," and we learned: they have redemption, and for their substitutes redemption, except for the firstborn and for the tithe, which implies they are not beneficial, the statement of Abbaye.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״הֵם״, בַּהֲוָויָיתָן יְהוּ.
human_translation: say to you: It is different there, as verse states: “They are they shall be as they are,
llm_translation: He said to you: it is different there, as the verse says "they," in their existence they are.

hebrew_text: וּלְרָבָא, הַאי ״הֵם״ לְמָה לֵיהּ? הֵן קְרֵיבִין, וְאֵין תְּמוּרָתָן קְרֵיבִין.
human_translation: And according to Rava, why does he “They are they, are sacrificed, but their substitutes, are not sacrificed.
llm_translation: And for Rava, this "they" - what is it for him? They are offerings, and their exchange is not offerings.

hebrew_text: וּלְאַבָּיֵי — הַאי סְבָרָא מְנָא לֵיהּ? ״אִם שׁוֹר אִם שֶׂה לַה׳ הוּא״ — לַה׳ קָרֵיב, וְאֵין תְּמוּרָתוֹ קְרֵיבָה.
human_translation: And according to Abaye, from where does he this conclusion “Whether it be ox or sheep, it is the Lord’s” is sacrificed to the Lord but its substitute is not sacrificed.
llm_translation: And to Abbaye - this opinion is satisfying to him? "Whether it is an ox or a sheep, it is for the Lord" - it is brought near to the Lord, and its exchange is not brought near.

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא, אִין הָכִי נָמֵי דְּמֵהָהוּא קְרָא, אֶלָּא ״הֵם״ לְמָה לִי? לִימֵּד עַל בְּכוֹר וּמַעֲשֵׂר שֶׁנִּתְעָרֵב דָּמָן בְּכׇל הָעוֹלִין שֶׁקְּרֵיבִין לְגַבֵּי מִזְבֵּחַ.
human_translation: And Rava Yes, is indeed so that from that verse, that Rather, why do I “They are teaches with regard to a firstborn or tithe whose blood was mixed with any brought upon that is sacrificed on the altar
llm_translation: Rava, thus it is said, the verse is not like them, rather "them" why do I need? To teach about the firstborn and the tithe whose blood is mixed in all the ascending offerings that are brought to the altar.

hebrew_text: וְאַבָּיֵי, הַאי סְבָרָא מְנָא לֵיהּ? מִ״וְּלָקַח מִדַּם הַפָּר וּמִדַּם הַשָּׂעִיר״, וַהֲלֹא דַּם הַפָּר מְרוּבֶּה מִשֶּׁל שָׂעִיר! מִיכָּן לָעוֹלִין שֶׁאֵין מְבַטְּלִין זֶה אֶת זֶה, דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְלָקַח מִדַּם הַפָּר וּמִדַּם הַשָּׂעִיר״ — שֶׁיְּהוּ מְעוֹרָבִין, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה.
human_translation: And Abaye, from where does he this conclusion, from “And he shall take of the blood of the bull, and of the blood of the goat, But isn’t there more blood of the bull than of the goat? From here that brought upon do not nullify one another, as it is taught “And he shall take of the blood of the bull, and of the blood of the goat” that they must be mixed. the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And Abbaye, does he hold this reasoning? "And he shall take of the blood of the bullock, and of the blood of the he-goat," but is not the blood of the bullock more abundant than that of the he-goat! From here they ascend that they do not nullify one another, as it was taught: "And he shall take of the blood of the bullock, and of the blood of the he-goat" — that they should be mixed, the words of Rabbi Yoshiyah.
