human_translation: From where are these matters as the Sages taught “An animal for an animal,” from here that one substitutes from the flock upon the herd, and from the herd upon the flock; from the sheep upon the goats, and from the goats upon the sheep; and from the males upon the females and from the females upon the males; and from the blemished upon the unblemished and from the unblemished upon the blemished
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara: Mana hanei milei? D'tanu Rabanan: "Behemah b'behemah" - mikkan she'memirin min ha'tzon al ha'bakar, u'min ha'bakar al ha'tzon, min ha'kevasim al ha'izzim, u'min ha'izzim al ha'kevasim, u'min ha'z'charim al ha'n'keivot, u'min ha'n'keivot al ha'z'charim, u'min ba'alei mumim al ha'temimim, u'min ha'temimim al ba'alei mumim.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל אֲפִילּוּ קָדַם מוּם לְהֶקְדֵּישָׁן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ וְלֹא יָמִיר אֹתוֹ טוֹב בְּרָע אוֹ רַע בְּטוֹב״, וְאֵיזֶהוּ ״טוֹב בְּרָע״? בַּעֲלֵי מוּמִין שֶׁקָּדַם הֶקְדֵּישָׁן אֶת מוּמָן.
human_translation: might even blemish preceded their consecration. the verse states: “He shall neither exchange it, nor substitute it, good for bad, or bad for good” and which is good for bad blemished whose consecration preceded their blemish.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Is it possible even if a blemish preceded to sanctify them? The Talmud teaches: "He shall not exchange it, nor substitute it, good for bad or bad for good." And what is "good for bad"? Owners of blemishes who sanctified their blemish.

hebrew_text: מַאי תַּלְמוּדָא? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: נֵימָא קְרָא ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ וְלֹא יָמִיר אֹתוֹ טוֹב בְּרָע אוֹ רַע בּוֹ״, ״בְּטוֹב״ אַחְרִינָא לְמָה לִי? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: טוֹב מֵעִיקָּרוֹ עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה, רַע מֵעִיקָּרוֹ אֵין עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה.
human_translation: What is the derivation Abaye said the verse should have stated: He shall neither exchange it, nor substitute it, good for bad, or bad for it. Why do I another “for good”? Learn from good, from its beginning, render a substitute bad from its beginning, cannot render a substitute
llm_translation: Talmudic text: What is the Talmud? Abaye said: Let us say the verse, "He shall not alter it, nor change it, a good for a bad, or a bad for a good" (Leviticus 27:10). Why do I need "a good" after it? Learn from it: A good from its inception can be exchanged, a bad from its inception cannot be exchanged.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: תַּרְוַויְיהוּ ״טוֹב״ יַיתּוֹרֵי מְיַיתְּרִי. אִם כֵּן, נִכְתּוֹב קְרָא ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ וְלֹא יָמִיר אוֹתוֹ בְּרָע אוֹ רַע בּוֹ״, לְמָה לִי לְמִכְתַּב תַּרְוַיְיהוּ ״טוֹב״? חַד ״טוֹב״ — אֲפִילּוּ בְּטוֹב נָמֵי, כִּי מֵמִיר לָקֵי. וְאִידַּךְ ״טוֹב״ — מֵעִיקָּרוֹ עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה, רַע מֵעִיקָּרוֹ אֵין עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה.
human_translation: Rava said: Both of “good” are superfluous. If so, let the verse write: He shall neither exchange it, nor substitute it for bad, or bad for it. Why do I to write both “good”? One “good” even for a good when he effects substitution flogged. And the other good from its beginning render a substitute bad from its beginning cannot render a substitute
llm_translation: Rava said: Their mutual agreement "good" overrides the prohibition of exchanging items. If so, it should be written in the verse "he shall not exchange it, nor substitute it, good for bad or bad for good," why do I need the word "good" in their agreement? One "good" - even with something that is inherently good, because he is exchanging it. And the other "good" - from its inception it makes an exchange, bad from its inception does not make an exchange.

hebrew_text: וְאַבָּיֵי אָמַר: קַל וָחוֹמֶר הוּא, וּמָה טוֹב בְּרָע, דְּעַלּוֹיֵי קָא מְעַלֵּי לֵיהּ — לָקֵי, טוֹב בְּטוֹב, דְּכִי הֲדָדֵי נִינְהוּ — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן דְּלָקֵי!
human_translation: And Abaye said: is an a fortiori Just as a good for a bad where improve flogged, not all the more so that a good for a good which are equivalent to each other, flogged?
llm_translation: And Abbaye said: It is a fortiori reasoning, and just as in a case of good with bad, where the bad is outweighed by the good - it is permissible, so too in a case of good with good, for when they are both equal - all the more so is it permissible!

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא — אֵין עוֹנְשִׁין מִן הַדִּין, וְאַבַּיֵּי אָמַר לָךְ: הָא לָאו דִּינָא הוּא, מִי גָּרַע טוֹב מֵרַע?
human_translation: And Rava one does not administer punishment on inference. And Abaye say to you this is not logical derivation, is a good, less than a bad
llm_translation: Rava — not punished from the law, and Abbaye said to you: this is not the law, who distinguishes good from evil?

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ״ בְּשֶׁל אֲחֵרִים, ״וְלֹא יָמִיר אוֹתוֹ״ בְּשֶׁל עַצְמוֹ. וְלִכְתּוֹב ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ״, וְלָא בָּעֵי ״לֹא יָמִיר אוֹתוֹ״!
human_translation: The Sages taught “He shall neither exchange it,” for that of others. “nor substitute it” for his own But let write “He shall not exchange it,” and no need “Nor substitute it,”
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "He shall not exchange it" for that of others, "and he shall not exchange it" for his own. And it is written "he shall not exchange it," and it does not require "he shall not exchange it"!

hebrew_text: אִי כְּתַב הָכִי — הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: תֵּצֵא זוֹ וְתִכָּנֵס זוֹ הוּא דְּתִילְקֵי, אֲבָל מֵמִיר דְּתַרְוַויְיהוּ קָא מַקְדֵּישׁ לְהוּ — אֵימָא לָא לָקֵי. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: If written that manner, I would say that flogged This should leave and this should enter But effects substitution as he has consecrated both of I would say not flogged. teaches us
llm_translation: If he wrote thus - I would say: "This one should go out and this one should come in," that is what he intended, but if he changes his mind and consecrates both of them - I would say: "No, he should not consecrate them." This is what we infer.

hebrew_text: הַאי בְּשֶׁל אֲחֵרִים, הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִי נֵימָא בְּהֵמָה דְּהֶקְדֵּשׁ דִּידֵיהּ, וְחוּלִּין דְּעָלְמָא — מִי מָצֵי מַקְדֵּישׁ? ״אִישׁ כִּי יַקְדִּישׁ אֶת בֵּיתוֹ קֹדֶשׁ לַה׳״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, מָה בֵּיתוֹ בִּרְשׁוּתוֹ, אַף כֹּל בִּרְשׁוּתוֹ. וְאֶלָּא בְּהֵמָה דְּהֶקְדֵּשׁ דְּעָלְמָא, וְחוּלִּין דִּידֵיהּ — מִי מַתְפֵּיס בְּדָבָר שֶׁאֵינוֹ שֶׁלּוֹ?
human_translation: What are the circumstances for that of others? If we say consecrated animal his and non-sacred to others, is he able to consecrate The Merciful One states “When a man shall consecrate his house to be sacred unto the Lord” just as his house is in his possession, so too, any in his possession. But rather, consecrated animal to others, and non-sacred his, can one effect for an item that is not his?
llm_translation: This is the case of using something belonging to others, what is the law? If we say it is an animal consecrated for itself, and regular mundane animals - who can sanctify? "When a man dedicates his house as holy to the Lord" the Merciful One said, just as his house is in his possession, so too everything is in his possession. Rather, if it is an animal consecrated for itself, and regular mundane animals - who can acquire something that is not his?

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם בִּבְהֵמָה דְּהֶקְדֵּשׁ דְּעָלְמָא, וְחוּלִּין דִּידֵיהּ, כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר מָרֵיהּ דִּבְהֵמָה דְּהֶקְדֵּשׁ: ״כׇּל הָרוֹצֶה לְהָמִיר בִּבְהֶמְתּוֹ יָבֹא וְיָמִיר״.
human_translation: Actually, to a consecrated of others and his non-sacred where the owner of the consecrated animal said whoever wants to effect substitution for his animal can come and effect substitution.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Always with an animal that is consecrated for the world, and its mundane counterpart, such as when one's master said regarding an animal that is consecrated: 'Anyone who wishes to exchange his animal, let him come and exchange.'"

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מְמִירִין אֶחָד בִּשְׁנַיִם, וּשְׁנַיִם בְּאֶחָד, אֶחָד בְּמֵאָה, וּמֵאָה בְּאֶחָד. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אֵין מְמִירִין אֶלָּא אֶחָד בְּאֶחָד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָיָה הוּא וּתְמוּרָתוֹ יִהְיֶה קֹּדֶשׁ״, מָה ״הוּא״ מְיוּחָד, אַף הִיא מְיוּחֶדֶת.
human_translation: One substitutes one for two and two for one one for one hundred and one hundred for one Rabbi Shimon says: One substitutes only one for one as it is stated: “Then both it and its substitute shall be sacred” Just as “it” specific so too, specific
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One may exchange one animal for two, and two for one, one for one hundred, and one hundred for one. Rabbi Shimon says: One may only exchange one for one, as it is stated: "And it shall be that he and its substitute shall be holy." Just as "he" is singular, so too is "it" singular.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״בְּהֵמָה בִּבְהֵמָה״ — מִכָּאן שֶׁמְּמִירִין אֶחָד בִּשְׁנַיִם, וּשְׁנַיִם בְּאֶחָד, אֶחָד בְּמֵאָה, וּמֵאָה בְּאֶחָד. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אֵין מְמִירִין אֶלָּא אֶחָד בְּאֶחָד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״בְּהֵמָה בִּבְהֵמָה״, וְלֹא בְּהֵמָה בִּבְהֵמוֹת, וְלֹא בְּהֵמוֹת בִּבְהֵמָה.
human_translation: From where are these matters As the Sages taught “An animal for an animal” From here one substitutes one for two and two for one one for one hundred and one hundred for one Rabbi Shimon says: One substitutes only one for one as it is stated: “An animal [ behema ] for an animal,” and not An animal for animals [ bivehemot ], nor: Animals for an animal.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemar mena hanei milei? D'tanu rabbana: "B'hemah bivhemah" — mikkan she'memirin echad bishnayim, ushnayim be'echad, echad beme'ah, ume'ah be'echad. Rabbi Shimon omer: Ein memirin ela echad be'echad, she'ne'emar "b'hemah bivhemah," v'lo b'hemah bivhemot, v'lo bivhemot bivhemah. English translation: What is the conclusion regarding these matters? For our Rabbis taught: "Animal for animal" — from here we learn that one may exchange one for two, and two for one, one for one hundred, and one hundred for one. Rabbi Shimon says: We only exchange one for one, as it is stated "animal for animal," not "animal for animals," and not "animals for animal."

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ: מָצִינוּ בְּהֵמוֹת שֶׁקְּרוּיָה ״בְּהֵמָה״, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּבְהֵמָה רַבָּה״. וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן — ״בְּהֵמָה רַבָּה״ אִיקְּרִי, ״בְּהֵמָה״ סְתָם לָא אִיקְּרִי.
human_translation: said to We have found that animals is called behema , as it is stated: “And many animals [ uvhema rabba ]” And Rabbi Shimon are called “ behema rabba ,” are not called “ behema ” without specification.
llm_translation: He said to him: We find in animals that are called "behemah," as it says: "and a great animal." And Rabbi Shimon - "behemah rabbah" is called, "behemah" alone is not called.

hebrew_text: וְטַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן מִשּׁוּם ״בְּהֵמָה״ הוּא? וְהָא טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן מִשּׁוּם ״הוּא״, מָה ״הוּא״ מְיוּחָד — אַף תְּמוּרָה מְיוּחֶדֶת!
human_translation: And is the reason of Rabbi Shimon due to “an animal But isn’t the reason of Rabbi Shimon, due to “it” Just as “it” specific so too, substitute specific
llm_translation: The reason of Rabbi Shimon is it because of "behemah"? And the reason of Rabbi Shimon is it because of "hu," just as "hu" is specific - so too, t'murah is specific!

hebrew_text: מֵעִיקָּרָא אָמַר לָהֶן רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן מִן ״וְהָיָה הוּא וּתְמוּרָתוֹ״, וְכִי חֲזָא דְּדָרְשִׁי רַבָּנַן מִ״בְּהֵמָה בִּבְהֵמָה״, אָמַר לָהֶם אִיהוּ: מֵהָתָם נָמֵי מָצֵינַן לְמֵילַף טַעְמָא דִּידִי.
human_translation: Initially, Rabbi Shimon stated to from “Then both it and its substitute.” But when he saw that the Rabbis taught from “an animal for an animal,” he said to them: You can learn the reason for my from there too.
llm_translation: From the outset, Rabbi Shimon said to them, "And he and his substitute." And did he see that the Rabbis expounded "from an animal to another animal"? He said to them: "From there we also find support for my reasoning."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: מוֹדֶה רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן שֶׁמְּמִירִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְמִירִין, מַאי טַעְמָא? קְדוּשָּׁה רִאשׁוֹנָה דְּהֶקְדֵּשׁ לְהֵיכָן הָלְכָה?! וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאֵין מְמִירִין שְׁנַיִם בְּאֶחָד, כֵּן אֵין מְמִירִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְמִירִין.
human_translation: Reish Lakish says: Rabbi Shimon concedes that one can effect substitution and then effect substitution again What is the reason Where has the initial consecration of the consecrated gone? And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: just as one cannot substitute two for one, so cannot effect substitution and then effect substitution again
llm_translation: Reish Lakish said: Rabbi Shimon concedes that we may exchange and exchange again. What is the reason? The first sanctity - where does it go? And Rabbi Yochanan said: Just as we do not exchange two for one, so too we do not exchange, exchange back, and exchange.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּוָותֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, תַּנְיָא כְּוָותֵיהּ דְּרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ. תַּנְיָא כְּוָותֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאֵין מְמִירִין אֶחָד בִּשְׁנַיִם, כָּךְ אֵין מְמִירִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְמִירִין. תַּנְיָא כְּוָותֵיהּ דְּרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: יָכוֹל כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן שֶׁאֵין מְמִירִין שְׁנַיִם בְּאֶחָד, כָּךְ אֵין מְמִירִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְמִירִין — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהָיָה הוּא וּתְמוּרָתוֹ״, אֲפִילּוּ בְּמֵאָה.
human_translation: is taught in accordance with of Rabbi Yoḥanan, is taught in accordance with of Reish Lakish. is taught in accordance with of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Just as cannot substitute one for two, so too, one cannot effect substitution and then effect substitution again. is taught in accordance with of Reish Lakish: might just as Rabbi Shimon said cannot substitute two for one, so too, one cannot effect substitution and then effect substitution again. the verse states: “Then both it and its substitute” with even one hundred
llm_translation: It was taught in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yochanan, it was taught in accordance with the opinion of Reish Lakish. It was taught in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yochanan: Just as one does not exchange one for two, so too one does not exchange, return, and exchange. It was taught in accordance with the opinion of Reish Lakish: One might have thought that just as Rabbi Shimon said that one does not exchange two for one, so too one does not exchange, return, and exchange - the Talmud teaches: "And it shall be he and his substitute," even a hundred.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבִּי אָבִין: לְדִבְרֵי הָאוֹמֵר ״אֵין מְמִירִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְמִירִין״, הִפְרִישׁ אָשָׁם לְהִתְכַּפֵּר בּוֹ, וְהֵמִיר בּוֹ,
human_translation: Rabbi Avin raises a dilemma: According to the statement of the one who says one cannot effect substitution and then effect substitution again, designated a guilt offering with which to atone and effected substitution for it,
llm_translation: The question of Rabbi Avin: According to the one who says, "We do not exchange back and forth and exchange back and forth," he separated a guilt-offering to atone with it, and he exchanged with it,

hebrew_text: וְהוּמַם וְחִלְּלוֹ עַל אַחֵר, וְנִתְכַּפֵּר בְּאָשָׁם אַחֵר, וְנִיתַּק לְעוֹלָה — מַהוּ שֶׁיָּמִיר בּוֹ?
human_translation: and became blemished, and he desacralized it onto another and achieved atonement by another, a guilt offering, and was consigned to a burnt offering, what is to he effect substitution for
llm_translation: "And he confused and desecrated it upon another, and atoned with another guilt-offering, and it was designated for a burnt-offering - what should he do with it?"

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מַאי קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ? אִי שְׁנֵי גוּפִים וּקְדוּשָּׁה אַחַת — תִּיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ בְּלֹא מִתְכַּפֵּר.
human_translation: Abaye said: What is the dilemma he is raising? If two bodies, and one sanctity. let the dilemma be raised in did not achieve atonement
llm_translation: Abaye said: What is he asking about? If there are two bodies and one sanctity - he should ask about it without atonement.

hebrew_text: אִי שְׁתֵּי קְדוּשּׁוֹת, וְגוּף אֶחָד — תִּיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ בְּלֹא הוּמַם!
human_translation: if two sanctity, one body. let the dilemma be raised did not become blemished
llm_translation: If two holy, and one body — it should be swallowed without hesitation!

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי אָבִין, חֲדָא מִגּוֹ חֲדָא קָמִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ, וְאִם תִּימְצֵי לוֹמַר: שְׁנֵי גוּפִין וּקְדוּשָּׁה אַחַת — לָא, מִשּׁוּם דִּבְהָהִיא קְדוּשָּׁה הָא אִיתְּמַר בַּהּ חֲדָא זִימְנָא. שְׁנֵי גוּפִין וּשְׁתֵּי קְדוּשּׁוֹת מַהוּ? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Avin raises one as a result of another If you say two bodies and one sanctity not because this sanctity had been substituted one time. what is two bodies and two sanctity? shall stand
llm_translation: Rabbi Avin, one from one asked him, and if you want to say: two bodies and one holiness - no, because that holiness that was mentioned in it one time. Two bodies and two holinesses, what is the law? It remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא, בָּעֵי רַבִּי אָבִין לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: דְּאָמַר אֵין מְמִירִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְמִירִין — הִפְרִישׁ אָשָׁם לְהִתְכַּפֵּר בּוֹ, וְהֵמִיר בּוֹ, וְהוּמַם וְחִלְּלוֹ עַל אַחֵר, מַהוּ שֶׁיַּחְזוֹר וְיָמִיר?
human_translation: an alternative version Rabbi Avin raises a dilemma: According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said one cannot effect substitution and then effect substitution again designated a guilt offering with which to achieve atonement and substituted for it, and became blemished and he desacralized it onto another what is to he can then effect substitution
llm_translation: The other student, Rabbi Avin, asked Rabbi Yochanan: For he said, "One does not exchange, then exchange again, and then exchange again." He separated a guilt offering to atone with it, and he exchanged it, and it became blemished and disqualified for another. What should he do, should he exchange it back?

hebrew_text: נִתְכַּפֵּר בְּאָשָׁם אַחֵר, וְנִיתַּק זֶה לְעוֹלָה, מַהוּ שֶׁיַּחֲזִיר וְיָמִיר?
human_translation: achieved atonement by another guilt offering, and was consigned to a burnt offering, what is to he can then effect substitution
llm_translation: He was atoned with a different guilt-offering, and this one was designated for a burnt-offering, what is the law if he should return and exchange it?

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הֵי קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ? קְדוּשָּׁה אַחֶרֶת בְּאוֹתוֹ הַגּוּף — לָא נִיבְעֵי הוּמַם וְחִלְּלוֹ בְּאַחֵר! אִי גּוּף (אֶחָד) [אַחֵר] בְּאוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה — לָא נִיבְעֵי נִתְכַּפֵּר בְּאָשָׁם אַחֵר!
human_translation: Abaye said: Which dilemma he is raising? another sanctity in the same body, he should not raise the dilemma became blemished and he desacralized it onto another if another body with the same sanctity, he should not raise the dilemma achieved atonement by another a guilt offering.
llm_translation: Abaye said: Is he asking about another sanctity in that same body? It will not be desecrated and profaned in another! If in another body in that same sanctity - it will not be atoned for with another guilt offering!

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי אָבִין, חֲדָא מִגּוֹ חֲדָא קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ: הוּמַם וְחִלְּלוֹ עַל אַחֵר, מַהוּ שֶׁיַּחֲזוֹר וְיָמִיר? מִי אָמְרִינַן: בְּאָשָׁם רִאשׁוֹן הוּא דְּאֵין חוֹזֵר וּמֵמִיר, אֲבָל בְּגוּף (אֶחָד) [אַחֵר], אַף עַל גַּב דְּקַדִּישׁ אוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה — חוֹזֵר וּמֵמִיר, אוֹ דִלְמָא: כֹּל בְּאוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה אֵין חוֹזֵר וּמֵמִיר?
human_translation: Rabbi Avin raises one as a result of another became blemished and he desacralized it onto another what is whether he then effect substitution Do we say is with the first guilt offering that he cannot effect substitution again, but with another body, even though it is sanctified with the same sanctity, he effect substitution again? Or perhaps any with the same sanctity, he cannot effect substitution again?
llm_translation: Rabbi Avin, one from one asks him: "If one blemishes and then consecrates it to another, can he go back and exchange it?" Do we say: with a guilt offering, it is such that he does not go back and exchange, but with another body, even though he sanctified it as holy - he goes back and exchanges, or perhaps: with any in that holiness, he does not go back and exchange?

hebrew_text: וְאִם תִּימְצָא לוֹמַר הַדִּין גּוּף (אֶחָד) [אַחֵר], כֵּיוָן דִּבְאוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה קָאֵים — אֵין חוֹזֵר וּמֵמִיר, אֶלָּא נִתְכַּפֵּר בְּאָשָׁם אַחֵר, וְנִיתַּק זֶה רִאשׁוֹן לְעוֹלָה, מַהוּ שֶׁיַּחֲזִיר וְיָמִיר בּוֹ?
human_translation: And if you say this other body, since it maintains the same sanctity cannot effect substitution again, but achieved atonement by another a guilt offering, and this first was consigned to a burnt offering? What is to he can effect substitution again
llm_translation: And if you might say the judgment is another body, since it stands in its holiness - it does not return and exchange, but is atoned for with another guilt offering, and the first one is severed for a burnt offering, what is the ruling regarding returning and exchanging it?

hebrew_text: מִי אָמְרִינַן: כִּי אֵין מֵמִיר וְחוֹזֵר וּמֵמִיר — הָנֵי מִילֵּי אוֹתוֹ הַגּוּף בְּאוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה, אֲבָל אוֹתוֹ הַגּוּף בִּקְדוּשָּׁה אַחֶרֶת — חוֹזֵר וּמֵמִיר, אוֹ דִלְמָא: אַף עַל קְדוּשָּׁה אַחֶרֶת, כֵּיוָן דְּאוֹתוֹ הַגּוּף הוּא — אֵין חוֹזֵר וּמֵמִיר? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: Do we say when cannot effect substitution and then effect substitution again, this statement the same body with the same sanctity, but the same body with another sanctity, he can effect substitution again? Or perhaps even concerning another sanctity, since it is the same body, he cannot effect substitution again shall stand
llm_translation: We say: When one exchanges and then re-exchanges - those words, that body in that holiness, but that body in another holiness - re-exchanges, or perhaps: even in another holiness, since that body is - does not re-exchange? This matter remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: הֶקְדֵּשׁ רִאשׁוֹן מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ, וְאֵין הֶקְדֵּשׁ שֵׁנִי מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: originally consecrated add one-fifth But consecrated second, does not add one-fifth
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: One who sanctifies the firstborn adds a fifth, but one who sanctifies the second does not add a fifth.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי? אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְאִם הַמַּקְדִּישׁ יִגְאַל אֶת בֵּיתוֹ וְיָסַף חֲמִישִׁית״ — מַקְדִּישׁ, וְלֹא הַמַּתְפִּיס.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi? The verse states: “And if he that consecrated it will redeem his house, then he shall add the fifth part who consecrates but not the one who applies
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi? The verse says: "And if the one who consecrated wishes to redeem his house, he shall add a fifth to its value" - he may consecrate, but he may not redeem.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבִּי אָבִין: הִפְרִישׁ אָשָׁם לְהִתְכַּפֵּר בּוֹ, וְהוּמַם, וְהוֹסִיף עָלָיו חוֹמֶשׁ, וְחִלְּלוֹ חֲבֵירוֹ, וְנִתְכַּפֵּר בְּאָשָׁם אַחֵר, וְנִיתַּק זֶה לְעוֹלָה — מַהוּ שֶׁיּוֹסִיף עָלָיו חוֹמֶשׁ?
human_translation: Rabbi Avin raises a dilemma designated a guilt offering by which to achieve atonement and it became blemished, and he added one-fifth to its and desacralized it, another and achieved atonement by another, a guilt offering, and consigned to a burnt offering, what is to add one-fifth to its
llm_translation: Inquires Rabbi Avin: He separated a guilt-offering to atone with it, and it became blemished, and he added a fifth to it, and his fellow desecrated it, and he atoned with another guilt-offering, and this one was designated for a burnt-offering - what is the law if he adds a fifth to it?

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מַאי קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ? אִי שְׁנֵי גוּפִין וּקְדוּשָּׁה אַחַת קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ — תִּיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ בְּלֹא נִתְכַּפֵּר!
human_translation: Abaye said: What is the dilemma he is raising? If he is raising a dilemma two bodies, one sanctity. let the dilemma be raised in did not achieve atonement
llm_translation: Abaye said: What is he asking about? If he is asking about two separate entities and one sanctity, he should ask about it without atonement!

hebrew_text: אִי שְׁתֵּי קְדוּשּׁוֹת, וְגוּף אֶחָד קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ — תִּיבְּעֵי בְּלֹא הוּמַם!
human_translation: if he is raising a dilemma two sanctity, one body. let the dilemma be raised in did not become blemished
llm_translation: If two sanctities, and one body is required for it - it should be required without blemish!

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי אָבִין, חֲדָא מִגּוֹ חֲדָא קָמִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ: אִם תִּימְצָא לוֹמַר שְׁנֵי גוּפִין וּקְדוּשָּׁה אַחַת לָא — מִשּׁוּם דִּבְהָהִיא קְדוּשָּׁה אִיתּוֹסַף בַּהּ חֲדָא זִימְנָא חוֹמֶשׁ, שְׁנֵי גוּפִין וּשְׁתֵּי קְדוּשּׁוֹת מַאי? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Avin raises one as a result of another If you say two bodies and one sanctity not because one-fifth was added once to with that sanctity. what two bodies and two sanctity? shall stand
llm_translation: Rabbi Avin, one from the other, asked him: If you can say two bodies and one sanctity - not because that sanctity is added to it one time a week, two bodies and two sanctities, what is the law? This remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא, בָּעֵי רַבִּי אָבִין: הִפְרִישׁ אָשָׁם לְהִתְכַּפֵּר בּוֹ, וְהוּמַם וְחִלְּלוֹ עַל אַחֵר וְהוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ, נִתְכַּפְּרוּ בְּאָשָׁם אַחֵר, וְנִיתַּק זֶה לְעוֹלָה — מַהוּ שֶׁיּוֹסִיף עָלָיו חוֹמֶשׁ?
human_translation: an alternative version Rabbi Avin raises a dilemma: designated a guilt offering with which to achieve atonement, and it became blemished and he desacralized onto another animal, and he added one-fifth achieved atonement by another, a guilt offering, and was consigned to a burnt offering, what is to add one-fifth to its
llm_translation: The other student asked, Rabbi Avin: If one separated a guilt-offering to atone with it, and it became blemished and disqualified for another, and he added a fifth, they were atoned for with another guilt-offering, and this one was designated for a burnt-offering — what is the law regarding adding a fifth upon it?

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הָדֵין קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ, אִי קְדוּשָּׁה אַחֶרֶת בְּאוֹתוֹ הַגּוּף קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ — לָא נִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ הוּמַם, אִי גּוּף (אֶחָד) [אַחֵר] בְּאוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה כּוּ׳.
human_translation: Abaye said: Which is dilemma he is raising? If he raises a dilemma another sanctity in the same body, he should not raise the dilemma became blemished if another body with the same sanctity,
llm_translation: Abaye said: Thus he inquires of him, if another sanctity in that body he inquires of him - not inquires of him, if another body in that sanctity so.

hebrew_text: וְחִלְּלוֹ עַל אַחֵר, מַהוּ שֶׁיּוֹסִיף עָלָיו חוֹמֶשׁ? מִי אָמְרִינַן: בְּאָשָׁם קַמָּא הוּא דְּמוֹסֵיף, אֲבָל בְּגוּף (אֶחָד) [אַחֵר], אַף עַל גַּב דְּקָאֵים בְּאוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה, [אֵין] מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ,
human_translation: and he desacralized it onto another, what is to add one-fifth to its Do we say with regard to first guilt offering he add but another body, even though it maintains the same sanctity adds one-fifth,
llm_translation: And they profane it on another, what is the law if one adds a fifth to it? Do we say: It is like a guilt offering that he adds, but in the case of another body, even though they are standing in that same sanctity, he does not add a fifth.

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִילְמָא: כׇּל אוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה אֵינוֹ מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ?
human_translation: Or perhaps any same sanctity he does not add one-fifth.
llm_translation: Or perhaps: does one not add interest to that sanctity?

hebrew_text: וְאִם תִּימָּצֵא לוֹמַר הָדֵין גּוּף (אֶחָד) [אַחֵר], כֵּיוָן דִּבְאוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה קָאֵים [אֵינוֹ] מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ, אֶלָּא נִתְכַּפֵּר בְּאַחֵר, וְנִיתַּק זֶה לְעוֹלָה — מַהוּ? כִּי [אֵינוֹ] מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ בְּאוֹתוֹ הַגּוּף בְּאוֹתָהּ קְדוּשָּׁה, אֲבָל בִּקְדוּשָּׁה אַחֶרֶת — לָא? אוֹ דִילְמָא, כֵּיוָן דְּאוֹתוֹ הַגּוּף הוּא — [אֵינוֹ] מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: And if you say this other body, since it maintains the same sanctity does not add one-fifth but achieved atonement by another, and this was consigned to a burnt offering? What is when does not add one-fifth, with regard to the same body with the same sanctity, but of another sanctity not Or perhaps since it is the same body, does not add one-fifth. shall stand
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And if you might suggest that the same body (another), since it stands in the same holiness, does not add a fifth, but is atoned for with another, and this is designated for a burnt offering - what is the ruling? For it does not add a fifth to that body in that holiness, but in a different holiness - no? Or perhaps, since that body itself - does not add a fifth? This matter remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: מַקְדִּישׁ מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ, אוֹ (מכפר) [מִתְכַּפֵּר] מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ? אָמַר רָבָא: אָמַר קְרָא ״וְאִם הַמַּקְדִּישׁ יִגְאַל אֶת בֵּיתוֹ״ — מַקְדִּישׁ, וְלֹא מִתְכַּפֵּר.
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma: one who consecrates add one-fifth or one atoning add one-fifth? Rava said the verse states: “And if he that consecrated it will redeem his house, one who consecrates but not one for whom atones.
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ramei bar Ḥama asked: If one consecrates, does he add a fifth, or if he atones, does he add a fifth? Rava said: The verse states, "But if the one who consecrated wishes to redeem his house" - he consecrates, and does not atone.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: מַקְדִּישׁ עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה, אוֹ מִתְכַּפֵּר עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה? אָמַר רָבָא: אִם כֵּן, מָצִינוּ צִיבּוּר וְשׁוּתָּפִין עוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה, כְּגוֹן דְּשַׁוּוֹ שָׁלִיחַ לְאַקְדּוֹשֵׁי.
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma: one who consecrates render a substitute or one achieving atonement render a substitute Rava said: If so, we find community or partners can render a substitute for example where they appointed an agent to consecrate
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ramei bar Ḥama asked: Is one who consecrates an offering making an exchange, or is one who atones making an exchange? Rava said: If so, we find that the community and partners make an exchange, for example, when a messenger is appointed for the sanctified items.

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד, דְּאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: תָּנָא ״קׇרְבָּנוֹ לַה׳ עַל נִזְרוֹ מִלְּבַד אֲשֶׁר תַּשִּׂיג יָדוֹ״, וְכִי נָזִיר נִידּוֹן בְּהֶשֵּׂג יָד? הָא כֵּיצַד? ״קׇרְבָּנוֹ לַה׳ עַל נִזְרוֹ״ — שֶׁהִפְרִישׁ מִשֶּׁלּוֹ, ״מִלְּבַד אֲשֶׁר תַּשִּׂיג יָדוֹ״ — שֶׁהִפְרִישׁוּ לוֹ אֲחֵרִים.
human_translation: And furthermore, Rav Naḥman says Rav Huna says: taught and of his offering unto the Lord for his naziriteship, besides that for which his means suffice; But is a nazirite judged according to his means? How this “his offering unto the Lord for his naziriteship” where he separated from his own “besides that for which his means suffice” where others separated for him.
llm_translation: And furthermore, as Rav Nachman said in the name of Rav Huna: It was taught in a Baraita, "His offering to the Lord, besides that which his hand can reach." Is a Nazirite judged based on what his hand can reach? How so? "His offering to the Lord, besides that which his hand can reach" - that he separated from his own, "besides that which his hand can reach" - that others separated for him.

hebrew_text: לְמַאי הִילְכְתָא? אִילֵּימָא לְעִנְיַן כַּפָּרָה — פְּשִׁיטָא דְּמִכַּפַּר לֵיהּ! אֶלָּא לְעִנְיַן תְּמוּרָה, וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: אַף כְּשֶׁהִפְרִישׁוּ לוֹ אֲחֵרִים — עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: בָּתַר מִתְכַּפֵּר אָזְלִינַן!
human_translation: With regard to what halakha If we say with regard to the matter of atonement, obvious that atone for him? Rather, with regard to substitution, and this is saying: Even where others separated for him, render a substitute Conclude from we follow one for whom atones,
llm_translation: For what purpose did he go? If you say it is for the matter of atonement - it is obvious that he goes to atone! Rather, it is for the matter of substitution, and thus he said: Even when others designated for him - he makes a substitution. Learn from it: After atonement, we go!

hebrew_text: לָא לְעִנְיַן תְּמוּרָה, וּדְקָא קַשְׁיָא לָךְ מַתָּנָה דְּקָא יָהֲבִין לֵיהּ — אִי לָאו דְּרַבִּי רַחֲמָנָא ״מִלְּבַד אֲשֶׁר תַּשִּׂיג יָדוֹ״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא גְּזֵירַת הַכָּתוּב הוּא ״קׇרְבָּנוֹ״ מִדִּידֵיהּ הוּא דְּמִכַּפַּר, מִדַּאֲחֵרִים לָא, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: not to substitution, And that which is difficult for you, they have given it to him as a gift, Had the Merciful One not included “besides that for which his means suffice,” I would say it is a Torah edict “his offering,” atone from his own but not from of others. teaches us
llm_translation: Regarding the matter of exchange, and it is difficult for you the gift that he gave to him — if not for the Merciful One's statement "besides what his hand can reach," I would say it is a decree of the Scripture, "his offering" is from his own, it is for atonement, from others it is not, this teaches us.

hebrew_text: מַאי הָוֵי עֲלַהּ? תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַקְדִּישׁ מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ, וּמִתְכַּפֵּר עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה.
human_translation: What was about this Come hear which Rabbi Abbahu said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: one consecrates he adds one-fifth But one for whom atones render a substitute
llm_translation: What is the law regarding it? Come and hear, for Rabbi Abahu said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: One who consecrates adds a fifth, and one who atones makes an exchange.

hebrew_text: תּוֹרֵם מִשֶּׁלּוֹ עַל שֶׁל אֲחֵרִים — טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה שֶׁלּוֹ. מַאי טַעְמָא? אָמַר קְרָא: ״אֶת כׇּל מַעְשַׂר תְּבוּאָתְךָ... וְנָתַתָּ וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: separates teruma from his to of others, benefit of discretion is his. What is the reason The verse states: all the tithe of your produce and have given
llm_translation: He who raises from his own upon that of others - his benefit is good. What is the reason? The verse says: "You shall surely tithe all the yield of your planting... and you shall give, etc."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין מְמִירִין, לֹא אֵבָרִין בְּעוּבָּרִין, וְלֹא עוּבָּרִין בְּאֵבָרִים, וְלֹא עוּבָּרִין וְאֵבָרִים בִּשְׁלֵימִים, וְלֹא שְׁלֵימִים בָּהֶן.
human_translation: One does not substitute limbs for fetuses, And not fetuses for limbs. And neither limbs nor fetuses for whole nor whole for
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One does not exchange, neither limbs for fetuses, nor fetuses for limbs, nor fetuses and limbs for whole animals, nor whole animals for them.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: מְמִירִין אֵבָרִים בִּשְׁלֵימִים, אֲבָל לֹא שְׁלֵימִים בָּהֶן. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: וַהֲלֹא בְּמוּקְדָּשִׁין, הָאוֹמֵר ״רַגְלָהּ שֶׁל זוֹ עוֹלָה״ — כּוּלָּהּ עוֹלָה, אַף כְּשֶׁיֹּאמַר ״רַגְלָהּ שֶׁל זוֹ תַּחַת זוֹ״ תְּהֵא כּוּלָּהּ תְּמוּרָה תַּחְתֶּיהָ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei says: One substitutes limbs for whole but not whole for Rabbi Yosei said: But isn’t with regard to sacrificial one says: The leg of this a burnt offering, the entire a burnt offering? So too, when he says: The leg of this in exchange for that the entire a substitute in exchange for it.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei says: We may exchange limbs with blemishes, but not blemishes with them. Rabbi Yosei said: But in the Temple, one who says, "The leg of this one is for an offering" — the entire animal is an offering, even if one says, "The leg of this one is beneath this one," the entire animal should be exchanged beneath it.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִתְּמַר, בַּר פְּדָא אָמַר: אֵין קְדוּשָּׁה חָלָה עַל עוּבָּרִין, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: קְדוּשָּׁה חָלָה עַל עוּבָּרִין. וְאַזְדָּא רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הִקְדִּישׁ חַטָּאת מְעוּבֶּרֶת וְיָלְדָה — רָצָה בָּהּ מִתְכַּפֵּר, רָצָה בִּוְולָדָהּ מִתְכַּפֵּר.
human_translation: It was stated Bar Padda says: Fetuses are not imbued with sanctity Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Fetuses are imbued with sanctity. And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his reasoning as Rabbi Yoḥanan said: one who consecrated a pregnant animal a sin offering, and it gave birth, he wishes he may achieve atonement by he wishes he may achieve atonement through offspring,
llm_translation: Gemara: It was stated: Bar Pedai said: Holiness does not take effect on fetuses. Rabbi Yochanan said: Holiness does take effect on fetuses. And Rabbi Yochanan supported his opinion, as Rabbi Yochanan said: If one consecrated a sin-offering that was a fetus and it was born — he is atoned for with it, he is atoned for with its offspring.

hebrew_text: וּצְרִיכָא, דְּאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן בְּהָךְ קַמַּיְיתָא — הָתָם הוּא דְּאַקְדְּשֵׁיהּ
human_translation: And necessary, As, if taught us this first there as he consecrated
llm_translation: And it is necessary, for if we were to hear in that case - there, it is he who sanctifies it.

hebrew_text: לְעוּבָּרָה גּוּפֵיהּ, אֲבָל הָכָא דְּאַקְדְּשַׁיהּ לְאִימֵּיהּ — הָא בִּכְלַל אִימֵּיהּ לָא קָדוֹשׁ.
human_translation: the fetus itself. But here, where he consecrated its mother, this is not consecrated along with its mother.
llm_translation: To the fetus itself, but here where he consecrated it to his mother - this is not included in the sanctity of his mother.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן בָּתְרָיְיתָא — הָתָם הוּא דְּאַקְדֵּישׁ לַהּ, וְכֹל דְּאִית בַּהּ, אֲבָל הָכָא דְּאַקְדְּשֵׁיהּ לֵיהּ — כֵּיוָן דְּלֵיתֵיהּ אַבָּרַאי, לָא קָדֵישׁ. צְרִיכָא.
human_translation: And if taught us this last it is there as he consecrated and all that is inside it, But here, where he consecrated itself, since is not outside not consecrated. necessary
llm_translation: And if we were to hear in the latter case - there, it is because he consecrated it to her, and anyone who has a share in it, but here, where he consecrated it to him - since he does not have a share in it, it is not consecrated. This is necessary.

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא, מַאי קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן? אִם שִׁיְּירוֹ — מְשׁוּיָּיר, וְעוּבָּר לָאו יֶרֶךְ אִמּוֹ הוּא, וְתַרְתֵּי לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: another version What is teaching us if he excluded excluded, And a fetus is not the thigh of its mother But why do I two
llm_translation: The other opinion, what does it teach us? If he left it - it is left, and a fetus is not its mother's thigh, and why do I need two?

hebrew_text: צְרִיכָא, דְּאִי אִתְּמַר בְּהָא — מִשּׁוּם דְּאִימֵּיהּ חַזְיָא לְגוּפֵיהּ, מִגּוֹ דְּנָחֲתָא קְדוּשָּׁה לַהּ נָחֲתָא נָמֵי לְוָלָד, אֲבָל אִידַּךְ — לָא. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן הָדָא.
human_translation: necessary, as, if it was stated with regard to that because its mother is fit to itself, since sanctity applies to her, it likewise applies to the offspring. But the other not teaches us this
llm_translation: The matter is, for if it were stated in this case — because his mother saw in him a resemblance to his father, from the moment of sanctification to the moment of birth, but in the other case — no. This is implied.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אִתְּמַר בְּהָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּקָא מְפָרֵשׁ קְדוּשָּׁה עַל (הָאֵם) הַוָּלָד, אֲבָל הָהִיא לָא צְרִיכָא.
human_translation: And if it was stated with regard to this because he expressly sanctity to the offspring. But that not necessary.
llm_translation: And if it is said in this regard, because he is explaining the sanctity upon the mother of the offspring, but that one is not necessary.

hebrew_text: יָתֵיב רַבִּי זֵירָא וְקָאָמַר לְהָא שְׁמַעְתָּא, אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה לְרַבִּי זֵירָא: כֵּיצַד מַעֲרִימִין עַל הַבְּכוֹר? הַמְבַכֶּרֶת שֶׁהָיְתָה מְעוּבֶּרֶת, אוֹמֵר: ״מָה שֶׁבְּמֵעֶיהָ שֶׁל זוֹ עוֹלָה״, יָלְדָה זָכָר — הֲרֵי זוֹ עוֹלָה, אַלְמָא קָדוֹשׁ עוּבָּר!
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira sat and stated this halakha Rabbi Yirmeya raised an objection to Rabbi Zeira How one employ artifice to the firstborn an animal give birth to its firstborn which is pregnant, say: That which is in the womb of this a burnt offering. gave birth to a male, it a burnt offering, Evidently, a fetus consecrated,
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira was sitting and saying this teaching, Rabbi Yirmeya raised a question to Rabbi Zeira: How do we heap upon the firstborn? If the firstborn was pregnant, she says, "Whatever is in her womb ascends," if she gives birth to a male - behold, this one ascends, implying that the fetus is considered holy even in utero!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כִּי מִתַּנְיָא הָהִיא בִּקְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים, מִי אַלִּימָא קְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים דְּקָא מַפְקְעָא לֵיהּ מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה?
human_translation: said to when that is taught, to sanctity value, Is sanctity value strong that it removes the firstborn from
llm_translation: He said to him: "For it is taught in the sanctity of blood, who can say that the sanctity of blood that is being removed from the firstborn?"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִין, וְהָתְנַן: כֹּל קָדָשִׁים שֶׁקָּדַם מוּם קָבוּעַ לְהֶקְדֵּישָׁן וְנִפְדּוּ — חַיָּיבִין בַּבְּכוֹרָה וּבַמַּתָּנוֹת. טַעְמָא דִּלְאַחַר שֶׁנִּפְדּוּ דְּחַיָּיבִין, אֲבָל קוֹדֶם שֶׁנִּפְדּוּ — פְּטוּרִין, [אַלְמָא] דְּאַלִּימָא קְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים דְּמַפְקַע לֵיהּ מִבְּכוֹרָה.
human_translation: said to him: Yes, and we learned All sacrificial which a permanent blemish preceded their consecration and they are redeemed are obligated, to, a firstborn, and to gifts reason that are obligated that they have already been redeemed. But before they are redeemed, exempt Evidently, sanctity value is strong to remove firstborn status from
llm_translation: He said to him: No, but didn't we learn: All consecrated animals that had a blemish before they were consecrated and were redeemed - are obligated in the laws of firstborn and gifts. The reason is that after they were redeemed they are obligated, but if it was before they were redeemed - they are exempt. This implies that the sanctity of the blood that is removed from them exempts them from the laws of firstborn.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: הָאוֹמֵר ״מָה שֶׁבְּמֵעֶיהָ שֶׁל זוֹ עוֹלָה״ — מוּתֶּרֶת בְּגִיזָּה וַאֲסוּרָה בַּעֲבוֹדָה, מִשּׁוּם כִּחוּשׁ עוּבָּר שֶׁבָּהּ! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָא נָמֵי קְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים.
human_translation: raised objection to one says: That which is in the womb of this a burnt offering, permitted to be shorn but is prohibited for labor, due to weakening of fetus that is inside it. said to This also sanctity value,
llm_translation: He raised an objection against him: One who says, "Whatever is in the womb of this one is an offering" — it is permitted for shearing but forbidden for labor, due to the fetus within it! He said to him: Indeed, the sanctity of blood.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אַלִּימָא קְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים, דְּאָסְירָא לֵיהּ בַּעֲבוֹדָה? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִין, וְהָתְנַן: יוֹצְאִין לְחוּלִּין, לִיגָּזֵז וְלֵיעָבֵד. טַעְמָא מִשּׁוּם דְּנִפְדּוּ, הָא קוֹדֶם שֶׁנִּפְדּוּ אֲסוּרִין בָּעֲבוֹדָה, אַלְמָא קְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים אָסְורִין לֵיהּ בַּעֲבוֹדָה.
human_translation: But is sanctity value strong that it renders prohibited for labor? said to Yes, and we learned emerge non-sacred be shorn and used for labor. reason that they were redeemed. before they are redeemed, they are prohibited for labor. Evidently, sanctity value renders prohibited for labor.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And who says that the sanctity of blood, that it prohibits him in the service? He said to him: No, and we learned: They may go out to profane use, to be sheared and to work. The reason is because they were redeemed, for before they were redeemed, they were prohibited in the service, which means that the sanctity of blood is prohibited in the service."

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: אֵין מְמִירִין לֹא אֵבָרִין בְּעוּבָּרִין, וְלֹא עוּבָּרִין בְּאֵבָרִין. אֵימוּרֵי הוּא דְּלָא מֵימַר, הָא מִיקְדָּשׁ — קָדְשִׁי!
human_translation: raised objection to One does not substitute limbs for fetuses, and not fetuses for limbs, it is a substitution that one cannot effect, consecrates consecrated,
llm_translation: He raised an objection: One does not exchange limbs for fetuses, nor fetuses for limbs. This is the statement that was said, that one should not say, "It is consecrated - My holy things!"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: בְּוַלְדֵי קָדָשִׁים הוּא דְּקַדִּישִׁי וְקָיְימִי.
human_translation: said to is to the offspring of sacrificial as they are already consecrated
llm_translation: He said to him: "It is the offspring of consecrated animals that I have consecrated and fulfilled."

hebrew_text: אִי וְלַד קָדָשִׁים, בִּמְעֵי אִמָּן הוּא דְּלָא עָבְדִין, הָא אַבָּרַאי — עָבְדִין, וְהָא תַּנְיָא: אֵין הַוָּלָד עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה!
human_translation: If the offspring of sacrificial it is in their mother’s womb that one cannot effect outside effect But isn’t it taught the offspring does not render a substitute?
llm_translation: Son of holy things, in the intestines of the mother he is not formed, this is the opinion of Abaye - they are formed, and this is what is taught: the fetus does not perform substitution!

hebrew_text: הָא מַנִּי? רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דְּאָמַר: הַוָּלָד עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה.
human_translation: whose is this It is Rabbi Yehuda, who said the offspring renders a substitute.
llm_translation: This is a question? Rabbi Yehuda it is, as he said: The newborn makes a substitution.

hebrew_text: אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, תְּמוּרָה הוּא דְּלָא עָבְדִי, הָא מִקְדָּשׁ — קָדְשִׁי, הָאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: אֵבָרִין לָא קָדְשִׁי! אֲמַר [לֵיהּ]: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — בְּאֵיבָר שֶׁהַנְּשָׁמָה תְּלוּיָה בּוֹ.
human_translation: If Rabbi Yehuda, it is substitution that one cannot perform consecrates consecrated doesn’t Rabbi Yehuda say limbs are not consecrated said What are we dealing with here? With a limb upon which life depends.
llm_translation: If Rabbi Yehuda, exchange it is that we do not do, this is the Temple - My holy things, this is what Rabbi Yehuda said: limbs are not My holy things! He said to him: What are we dealing with here - with a limb upon which the soul depends.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: מַקְדִּישִׁין אֵבָרִין וְעוּבָּרִין, אֲבָל לֹא מְמִירִין! הָכָא נָמֵי בְּוַלְדֵי קָדָשִׁים.
human_translation: raised objection to One consecrates limbs and fetuses but one does not substitute Here too, to the offspring of sacrificial
llm_translation: He raised an objection to it: One may sanctify limbs and fetuses, but one may not exchange them! Here too, we are dealing with consecrated offspring.

hebrew_text: אִי בְּוַלְדֵי קָדָשִׁים, מַאי ״מַקְדִּישִׁין״? הָא קַדִּישִׁי וְקָיְימִי!
human_translation: If to the offspring of sacrificial what One consecrates? are already consecrated
llm_translation: If with offspring of holy things, what is "makdishin"? The holy one and established!

hebrew_text: הָכִי קָאָמַר: מַקְדִּישִׁין אֵיבָרִין וּמְמִירִין בָּהֶן, אֲבָל לֹא מְמִירִין בָּהֶן, וְעוּבָּרִים שֶׁקָּדְשׁוּ בִּמְעֵי אִמָּן אֵין מְמִירִין בָּהֶן.
human_translation: this is saying: One consecrates limbs, And one substitutes But one does not substitute for And fetuses that were consecrated in their mother’s womb one does not substitute for them
llm_translation: So it is stated: We may sanctify limbs and exchange them, but we may not exchange them, and fetuses that were sanctified in their mother's womb, we do not exchange them.

hebrew_text: בְּוַלְדֵי קָדָשִׁים, בִּמְעֵי אִמָּן — הוּא דְּלָא עָבְדִין תְּמוּרָה, הָא אַבָּרַאי — עָבְדִי. וְהָא תְּנַן: אֵין הַוְּולָדוֹת עוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה! הָא מַנִּי? רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא.
human_translation: to the offspring of sacrificial it is in their mother’s womb that one may not render a substitute outside one can render But didn’t we learn the offspring do not render a substitute? whose is this It is Rabbi Yehuda,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Buldei kadashim, bimei iman — hu de'lav avdin temurah, ha abarai — avdi. Ve'ha tenan: Ein havuladot osin temurah! Ha mani? Rabbi Yehuda hi. English translation: The offspring of consecrated animals, in the womb of their mother — that which we do not perform an exchange for, this one — we do perform an exchange for. And we learned: The offspring do not effect an exchange! How so? This is according to Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, אֵבָרִין מִי קָדְשִׁי? הָא לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה לֵית לֵיהּ הָאוֹמֵר ״רַגְלָהּ שֶׁל זוֹ עוֹלָה״ — כּוּלָּהּ עוֹלָה!
human_translation: If Rabbi Yehuda, are limbs consecrated But Rabbi Yehuda does not accept one says: The leg of this a burnt offering, the entire a burnt offering.
llm_translation: If it is Rabbi Yehuda, limbs of animals who sanctifies? This is to Rabbi Yehuda, there is not to him the one saying "its leg that of this animal is ascending" - all of it ascends!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — בְּדָבָר הָעוֹשֶׂה אוֹתָהּ טְרֵפָה.
human_translation: said to What are we dealing with here? with an item whose renders it a tereifa ,
llm_translation: He said to him: Here, with what are we dealing? - With a matter that renders it a treifah.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי: הַשּׁוֹחֵט אֶת הַחַטָּאת, וּמָצָא בָּהּ בֶּן אַרְבַּע חַי, קָתָנֵי חֲדָא: אֵינָהּ נֶאֱכֶלֶת אֶלָּא לְזִכְרֵי כְהוּנָּה, וְאֵינָהּ נֶאֱכֶלֶת אֶלָּא לִפְנִים מִן הַקְּלָעִים, וְאֵינָהּ נֶאֱכֶלֶת אֶלָּא לְיוֹם אֶחָד.
human_translation: Let us say is parallel to tanna’im , one slaughtered a sin offering, and he found inside it four old, alive, one teaches: it is eaten only by the males of the priesthood, and is eaten only within the hangings, and is eaten only for one day
llm_translation: Let us say according to the Tannaim: One who slaughters the sin-offering, and found within it a four-legged offspring, it is taught in one teaching: It is not eaten except for the sake of the male priests, and it is not eaten except within the curtains, and it is not eaten except for one day.

hebrew_text: וְתַנְיָא אִידַּךְ: נֶאֱכֶלֶת לְכׇל אָדָם, וְנֶאֱכָלִין בְּכׇל מָקוֹם, וְאֵינָן נֶאֱכָלִין בַּעֲזָרָה. מַאי לָאו תַּנָּאֵי הִיא? דְּמָר סָבַר: קְדוּשָּׁה חָלָה עַל עוּבָּרִין, וּמַר סָבַר: אֵין קְדוּשָּׁה חָלָה עַל עוּבָּרִין.
human_translation: And it is taught another it is eaten by any person, and may be eaten anywhere but they may not be eaten in the courtyard. What, is it not is tanna’im , as Sage, holds fetuses are imbued with sanctity, and Sage, holds fetuses are not imbued with sanctity,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught in another Baraita: It is fit for consumption by all people, and it is consumed in all places, but it is not consumed in the Azarah. What is the reason? Is it not because it is a dispute of Tannaim? For one Sage holds: Sanctity applies to fetuses, and the other Sage holds: Sanctity does not apply to fetuses.

hebrew_text: לָא, הָנֵי תַּנָּאֵי בְּהָא קָא מִיפַּלְגִי, דְּמָר סָבַר: וַלְדוֹת קָדָשִׁים בַּהֲוָיָיתָן הֵן קְדוֹשִׁים, וּמָר סָבַר: וַלְדֵי קָדָשִׁים בִּמְעֵי אִמָּן הֵן קְדוֹשִׁים.
human_translation: No, these tanna’im disagree about this, as Sage, holds offspring of sacrificial when they come into being, are they sanctified. And Sage, holds offspring of sacrificial are sanctified in their mother’s womb,
llm_translation: Not, these scholars in this are arguing, as Master holds: "The offspring of holy things are themselves holy," and as the other Master holds: "The offspring of holy things in the wombs of their mothers are holy."

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא, חַד תַּנָּא הוּא, חֲדָא מֵהָלֵין מַתְנְיָיתָא — בְּמַקְדִּישׁ בְּהֵמָה וְאַחַר כָּךְ נִתְעַבְּרָה, וַחֲדָא מִנְּהוֹן — שֶׁהִקְדִּישָׁהּ מְעוּבֶּרֶת.
human_translation: And if you wish, say it is one tanna one of these baraitot to one consecrates an animal and it became pregnant afterward. And one of where he consecrated pregnant,
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: It is one Tanna, one of them teaches in a Baraita - if one consecrated an animal and afterwards it became pregnant, and one of them - that it was consecrated while pregnant.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: כִּלְאַיִם, וּטְרֵפָה, וְיוֹצֵא דּוֹפֶן, טוּמְטוּם, וְאַנְדְּרוֹגִינוֹס — לֹא קְדוֹשִׁין וְלֹא מַקְדִּישִׁין. וְאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: לֹא קְדוֹשִׁין בִּתְמוּרָה, וְלֹא מַקְדִּישִׁין לַעֲשׂוֹת תְּמוּרָה.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Eliezer says: diverse kinds, and a tereifa , and born by caesarean section, whose sexual organs are indeterminate [ tumtum ], and a hermaphrodite [ ve’androginos ] are neither sacred nor do they sanctify And Shmuel says, are not sacred as a substitute, And do not sanctify to render a substitute;
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says: Kil'ayim, and a treifah, and a yotzei dofen, tumtum, and androgynos - they are not sanctified and do not sanctify. And Shmuel said: They are not sanctified through exchange, and one does not sanctify to make an exchange.

hebrew_text: וְתַנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר: מֵאַחַר שֶׁאֵינָן קְדוֹשִׁין, הֵיאַךְ מַקְדִּישִׁין? אִי אַתָּה מוֹצֵא אֶלָּא בְּמַקְדִּישׁ בְּהֵמָה וְאַחַר כָּךְ נִטְרְפָה, בְּמַקְדִּישׁ וָלָד וְיָצָא [דֶּרֶךְ] דּוֹפֶן. אַלְמָא קָדֵישׁ וָלָד!
human_translation: And it is taught Rabbi Meir said: since they are not sanctified, how could they sanctify You find only where one consecrated an animal and subsequently it became a tereifa , where one consecrated offspring and it was born by caesarean section. evidently an offspring can be sanctified
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught, Rabbi Meir said: Since they are not holy, how can we sanctify them? If you can only find a case where one sanctifies an animal and afterwards it becomes blemished, then one sanctifies and a child is born and exits the womb. Therefore, sanctify a child!

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: בְּתָם בִּמְעֵי תְמִימָה, אֲפִילּוּ בַּר פְּדָא נָמֵי מוֹדֵי דְּקָדֵישׁ. לֹא נֶחְלְקוּ אֶלָּא בְּתָם בִּמְעֵי בַּעֲלַת מוּם. בַּר פְּדָא סָבַר: כֵּיוָן דְּאִימֵּיהּ לָא מִקַּדְּשָׁא קְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף, הוּא נָמֵי לָא קָדֵישׁ. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סָבַר: הָנֵי כִּשְׁתֵּי בְהֵמוֹת נִינְהוּ, אִימֵּיהּ הִיא דְּלָא מִיקַּדְּשָׁא, אֲבָל הוּא קָדוֹשׁ.
human_translation: say of an unblemished in the womb of an unblemished even bar Padda concedes that it can be consecrated. disagree only with regard to an unblemished in the womb of a blemished Bar Padda maintains since its mother cannot be consecrated with inherent sanctity, is not consecrated either. And Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains: These are as two animals; it is its mother that is not consecrated, but consecrated.
llm_translation: They said: In the case of a completely unblemished animal, even Bar Pada the grandson of Modai agrees that it is sanctified. They only disagreed in the case of an unblemished animal belonging to a blemished owner. Bar Pada holds: Since its mother is not sanctified, it is also not sanctified. But Rabbi Yochanan holds: They are like two animals, its mother is not sanctified, but it is sanctified.

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא, אֲבָל כִּלְאַיִם וְטוּמְטוּם וְאַנְדְּרוֹגִינוֹס, אִי אַתָּה מוֹצֵא אֶלָּא בְּוַלְדֵי קֳדָשִׁים.
human_translation: another version But diverse kinds, and a tumtum , and a hermaphrodite, you find only when offspring of sacrificial
llm_translation: The other one, but Kil'ayim and Tumtum and Androgynos, if you do not find except in the offspring of holy ones.

hebrew_text: וּכְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, שֶׁהָיָה אוֹמֵר: הַוָּלָד עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה. הָלֵין הוּא דְּלָא קָדְשִׁי גּוּפַיְיהוּ, אֲבָל עוּבָּרִין אֲחֵרִים קְדוֹשִׁין!
human_translation: And in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, who would say the offspring renders a substitute. It is these as they cannot have inherent sanctity, but other fetuses, can be consecrated,
llm_translation: And like Rabbi Yehuda, who used to say: A newborn makes a substitution. It is a disgrace that they did not sanctify themselves, but other embryos are holy!

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: תָּם בִּמְעֵי תְּמִימָה — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל קָדֵישׁ גּוּפֵיהּ, אֶלָּא כִּי פְּלִיגִי בִּמְעֵי בַּעֲלַת מוּם, דְּבַר פְּדָא סָבַר: כֵּיוָן דְּאִימֵּיהּ נָמֵי לָא קָדֵישׁ גּוּפַהּ — אִיהוּ נָמֵי לָא קָדֵישׁ אֶלָּא לִדְמֵי, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סָבַר: עוּבָּר לָאו יֶרֶךְ אִמּוֹ הוּא, וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּאִימֵּיהּ לָא קָדְשָׁה לְגוּפַהּ — וָלָד מִיהָא קָדֵישׁ לְגוּפֵיהּ.
human_translation: Abaye said: an unblemished in the womb of an unblemished everyone agrees that can have inherent sanctity. Rather, when disagree, in the womb of a blemished As bar Padda maintains: Since even its mother cannot have inherent sanctity, too can be consecrated only for value. Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains: A fetus is not the thigh of its mother and even though its mother’s sanctity is not inherent, the sanctity of offspring can still be inherent.
llm_translation: Abaye said: "If the fetus is complete in its mother's womb - everyone agrees that it is holy in its entirety. However, when they dispute regarding the fetus of a blemished woman, Pedah's statement is: Since its mother is not holy, it is also not holy in itself. Rabbi Yochanan holds: The fetus is not considered a thigh of its mother, and even though its mother is not holy in herself, the fetus is holy in its entirety."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: וַהֲלֹא בְּמוּקְדָּשִׁין, הָאוֹמֵר ״רַגְלָהּ שֶׁל זוֹ״ כּוּ׳.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei said But isn’t with regard to sacrificial one says: The leg of this
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yosei: And isn't it in the Temple, one who says "her leg" etc.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: יָכוֹל הָאוֹמֵר ״רַגְלָהּ שֶׁל זוֹ עוֹלָה״ תְּהֵא כּוּלָּהּ עוֹלָה? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כֹּל אֲשֶׁר יִתֵּן מִמֶּנּוּ לַה׳ יִהְיֶה קֹּדֶשׁ״ — מִמֶּנּוּ לַה׳, וְלֹא כּוּלּוֹ לַה׳.
human_translation: The Sages taught: might one says: The leg of this is a burnt offering, all of will be a burnt offering. the verse states: anything of it that one gives to the Lord, it shall be sacred” of it unto the Lord, and not all of unto the Lord.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: Can one who says, "Her leg shall ascend" mean that her entirety shall ascend? The verse teaches: "Everything that one gives from it to the Lord shall be holy" - from it to the Lord, and not all of it to the Lord.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל תֵּצֵא לְחוּלִּין? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״יִהְיֶה קֹּדֶשׁ״. הָא כֵּיצַד? תִּמָּכֵר לְצׇרְכֵי עוֹלוֹת, וְדָמֶיהָ חוּלִּין, חוּץ מִדְּמֵי אֵבֶר שֶׁבָּהּ — דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: might transferred to non-sacred the verse states: “Shall be sacred,” How this should be sold for the needs of burnt offerings and the payment for non-sacred, except for the payment for limb of the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Is it possible for it to go out to ordinary use? The Torah says, "It shall be holy." How so? One may sell it for the needs of burnt offerings, and its blood is ordinary i.e., not holy, except for the blood of its limb — the words of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: מִנַּיִן לָאוֹמֵר ״רַגְלָהּ שֶׁל זוֹ עוֹלָה״, שֶׁכּוּלָּהּ עוֹלָה? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כֹּל אֲשֶׁר יִתֵּן מִמֶּנּוּ לַה׳״, כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר ״יִהְיֶה קֹדֶשׁ״ — לְרַבּוֹת אֶת כּוּלָּהּ.
human_translation: But Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say: From where one who says: The leg of this is a burnt offering, that all of it becomes a burnt offering? Since it is stated: “All that any man give of such to the Lord When it says: “Shall be sacred,” to include all of
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say: From where do we derive that one does not say, "its leg that is offered up," that the entire animal is offered up? As it is stated: "Everything that one gives from it to the Lord," when it says, "it shall be holy" - to include its entirety.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: תִּמָּכֵר לְצׇרְכֵי עוֹלוֹת, וְהָא קָמַיְיתֵי בְּהֵמָה מְחוּסֶּרֶת אֵבֶר? אָמַר רָבָא: בְּאוֹמֵר ״הֲרֵי עָלַי עוֹלָה בְּחַיֶּיהָ״.
human_translation: The Master said: should be sold for the needs of burnt offerings. But bringing an animal lacks limb Rava says: to one who says: It upon me a burnt offering with its life
llm_translation: Master said: "Sell for the needs of burnt offerings, and here you are standing with an animal lacking a limb?" Rava said: By saying, "Behold, I have an olah offering in its living state."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: מוֹדֶה רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּדָבָר שֶׁעוֹשֶׂה אוֹתָהּ טְרֵפָה. רָבָא אָמַר: בְּדָבָר שֶׁעוֹשֶׂה אוֹתָהּ נְבֵילָה. וְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת אָמַר: בְּדָבָר שֶׁהִיא מֵתָה.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda says Rabbi Yehuda concede with regard to whose renders a tereifa . Rava says: with regard to whose renders it an animal carcass, And Rav Sheshet says: with regard to whose it die
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: Rabbi Yehuda concedes regarding something that makes it a treifah. Rava said: regarding something that makes it a neveilah. And Rav Sheshet said: regarding something that is already dead.

hebrew_text: מַאי אִיכָּא בֵּין רַב חִסְדָּא לְרָבָא? אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ טְרֵפָה חַיָּה. רַב חִסְדָּא סָבַר לַהּ כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר טְרֵפָה אֵינָהּ חַיָּה, וְרָבָא סָבַר לַהּ כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר טְרֵפָה חַיָּה.
human_translation: What is there between Rav Ḥisda and Rava? between them a tereifa can survive. Rav Ḥisda holds in accordance with the one who said a tereifa cannot survive And Rava holds in accordance with the one who says a tereifa can survive,
llm_translation: What is the difference between Rav Ḥisdah and Rava? The difference between them is regarding a living treifah animal. Rav Ḥisdah holds like the one who says a treifah is not considered alive, and Rava holds like the one who says a treifah is considered alive.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי אִיכָּא בֵּין רָבָא לְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת? אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ דְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: נִיטְּלָה יָרֵךְ וְחָלָל שֶׁלָּהּ — נְבֵילָה. רָבָא סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, רַב שֵׁשֶׁת לָא סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר.
human_translation: And what is there between Rava and Rav Sheshet? between them of Rabbi Elazar, as Rabbi Elazar said: the thigh, and its recess were removed, a carcass Rava holds in accordance with Rabbi Elazar, Rav Sheshet does not hold in accordance with Rabbi Elazar,
llm_translation: And what is the difference between Rava and Rav Sheshet? The difference between them is regarding the statement of Rabbi Elazar, for Rabbi Elazar said: If its thigh and its hollow were removed - it is a carcass. Rava holds like Rabbi Elazar, but Rav Sheshet does not hold like Rabbi Elazar.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: אָמַר רַבִּי: נִרְאִין דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּדָבָר שֶׁאֵין הַנְּשָׁמָה תְּלוּיָה בּוֹ, וְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּדָבָר שֶׁהַנְּשָׁמָה תְּלוּיָה בּוֹ. לָאו מִכְּלָל דִּפְלִיג עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה?
human_translation: raises an objection: Rabbi said: the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, appears with regard to upon which life does not depend, and the statement of Rabbi Yosei with regard to upon which life depends. not by inference that disagrees with Rabbi Yehuda
llm_translation: Challenger: Said Rabbi: Appear the words of Rabbi Yehuda in a matter that the soul is not dependent on it, and the words of Rabbi Yosei in a matter that the soul is dependent on it. Is it not from the general principle that Rabbi Yehuda disagrees with it?

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא נִרְאִין דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּדָבָר שֶׁאֵין הַנְּשָׁמָה תְּלוּיָה בּוֹ, מִכְּלָל דִּפְלִיג עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי. אֶלָּא נִרְאִין דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּדָבָר שֶׁהַנְּשָׁמָה תְּלוּיָה בּוֹ — לָאו מִכְּלָל דִּפְלִיג עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? וּתְיוּבְתָּא דְּכוּלְּהוּ!
human_translation: Granted, The statement of Rabbi Yehuda appears with regard to upon which life does not depend, by inference that disagrees with Rabbi Yosei But the statement of Rabbi Yosei appears with regard to upon which life depends, not by inference that disagrees with Rabbi Yehuda And a conclusive refutation of all
llm_translation: In peace, the words of Rabbi Yehuda are seen regarding a matter in which the soul is not dependent on it, from which it can be inferred that Rabbi Yosei disagrees with him. Rather, the words of Rabbi Yosei are seen regarding a matter in which the soul is dependent on it - is this not an indication that Rabbi Yehuda disagrees with him? And the resolution is that they both agree!

hebrew_text: לָא, חַסּוֹרֵי מִיחַסְּרָא וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: נִרְאִין דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּדָבָר שֶׁהַנְּשָׁמָה תְּלוּיָה בּוֹ, שֶׁאַף רַבִּי יְהוּדָה לֹא נֶחְלַק עָלָיו אֶלָּא בְּדָבָר שֶׁאֵין הַנְּשָׁמָה תְּלוּיָה בּוֹ, אֲבָל בְּדָבָר שֶׁהַנְּשָׁמָה תְּלוּיָה בּוֹ מוֹדֵי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: No, is incomplete, and this it is teaching: The statement of Rabbi Yosei appears to Rabbi Yehuda of upon which life depends, as even Rabbi Yehuda disagreed with only with regard to upon which life does not depend. But with regard to upon which life depends, concedes to him
llm_translation: Not lacking from lacking and thus it was taught: The words of Rabbi Yosei appear to Rabbi Yehuda regarding a matter in which the soul is dependent upon it, for even Rabbi Yehuda only disputes him in a matter in which the soul is not dependent upon it, but in a matter in which the soul is dependent upon it, he agrees with him.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָבָא: בָּעוֹף מַהוּ? ״בְּהֵמָה״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, וְהָא לָאו ״בְּהֵמָה״ הִיא, אוֹ דִלְמָא ״קׇרְבָּן״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, וְהַאי נָמֵי ״קׇרְבָּן״ הוּא? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: Rava raises a dilemma: With regard to a bird what is the Merciful One states “animal,” and this not an animal. Or perhaps the Merciful One states “offering,” and this also an offering. shall stand
llm_translation: Rava asked: In the case of a bird, what is it? "Behemah" (animal) the Merciful One said, but is it not that it is not "behemah," or perhaps the Merciful One said "korban" (sacrifice), and this too is "korban"? This remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָבָא: הִקְדִּישׁ אֵבֶר לְדָמָיו, מַהוּ דְּתֵיחוֹת לֵיהּ קְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף? מִי אָמַר: כֵּיוָן דְּנָחֲתָא לֵיהּ קְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים — נָחֲתָא לֵיהּ נָמֵי קְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף, וּמִדְּאַקְדְּשֵׁיהּ לְחַד אֵבֶר — אַקְדְּשַׁיהּ לְכוּלַּהּ, אוֹ דִלְמָא חַד מִגּוֹ אָמַר, תְּרֵי מִגּוֹ לָא אָמַר?
human_translation: Rava raises dilemma: consecrated a limb its payment, what is to is imbued with inherent sanctity? Does say since it is imbued with sanctity value, it is likewise imbued with inherent sanctity, and that he consecrated one limb he has consecrated the entire Or perhaps says Since, once, not say two Since,
llm_translation: Ba'ei Rava: He sanctified a limb for its blood, what is the law regarding the sanctity of the body? Who said: since the sanctity of the blood has rested upon it, the sanctity of the body has also rested upon it, and if he sanctified one limb - he sanctified all of it, or perhaps one individual said this, and two individuals did not say it?

hebrew_text: תִּפְשׁוֹט לֵיהּ מִדִּידֵיהּ, דְּהָאָמַר רָבָא: הִקְדִּישׁ זָכָר לְדָמָיו — קָדוֹשׁ קְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף!
human_translation: Resolve by own As, didn’t Rava say: one consecrated a male for its value, consecrated inherent sanctity?
llm_translation: He should divorce her from his own accord, for Rava said: "If one consecrated a male for his own blood - he is holy, the holiness of the body!"

hebrew_text: הָתָם — דְּאַקְדְּשֵׁיהּ לְכוּלֵּיהּ, הָכָא — דְּאַקְדְּשֵׁיהּ חַד אֵבֶר, מַאי? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: There, where he consecrated all of it, Here, where he consecrated one limb What shall stand
llm_translation: There — that he sanctified it for all, here — that he sanctified it one limb, what? Let it stand.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי מִינֵּיהּ [אַבָּיֵי] מֵרָבָא: הִקְדִּישׁ חַד אֵבֶר, מַהוּ בְּגִיזָּה? תִּפְשׁוֹט לָךְ מֵהָא דְּתַנְיָא: ״לֹא תָגוֹז בְּכוֹר צֹאנְךָ״, אֲבָל אַתָּה גּוֹזֵז בְּשֶׁלְּךָ וְשֶׁל אֲחֵרִים.
human_translation: posed a dilemma to Rava: consecrated one limb, what is with regard to shearing You resolve from that which is taught “Nor shear the firstborn of your flock” but you may shear of belongs to you and to others,
llm_translation: Inquiries of Abaye from Rava: If one consecrated a limb, what about its fleece? Resolve it for yourself from what was taught: "You shall not shear the firstborn of your flock," but you may shear your own and that of others.

hebrew_text: הָתָם, לָא נָחֲתָא לֵיהּ קְדוּשָּׁה כְּלָל; הָכָא, נָחֲתָא לֵיהּ קְדוּשָּׁה. לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא: הָתָם, אֵין בְּיָדוֹ לְהַקְדִּישׁוֹ; הָכָא, בְּיָדוֹ לְהַקְדִּישׁוֹ.
human_translation: There, was not imbued with sanctity at all, here it was imbued with sanctity, another version There, it is not in power to consecrate here it is in his power to consecrate
llm_translation: There, not descended to him holiness in general; here, descended to him holiness. To another case: there, not in his hand to sanctify it; here, in his hand to sanctify it.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ אַבָּיֵי מֵרָבָא: הִקְדִּישׁ עוֹרָהּ, מַהוּ בַּעֲבוֹדָה? תָּא שְׁמַע: הָאוֹמֵר ״מָה שֶׁבְּמֵעֶיהָ שֶׁל זוֹ עוֹלָה״ — מוּתֶּרֶת בְּגִיזָּה, וַאֲסוּרָה בַּעֲבוֹדָה, מִפְּנֵי כִּחוּשׁ עוּבָּר שֶׁבָּהּ.
human_translation: Abaye posed a dilemma to Rava: consecrated the skin of what is to for labor? Come hear one who says: That which is in the womb of this is a burnt offering, permitted to be shorn but is prohibited for labor, due to weakening of the fetus inside it.
llm_translation: Abaye asked Rava: If she consecrated her skin, what about Avodah (service)? Come and hear: One who says, "Whatever is in the womb of this one is an offering" — it is permitted for shearing, and forbidden for service, due to the fetus within her.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כִּי קָתָנֵי אֲסוּרָה בַּעֲבוֹדָה — מִדְּרַבָּנַן. אִי הָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ בְּגִיזָּה נָמֵי תִּיתְּסַר! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: עֲבוֹדָה דְּמַיכְחֲשָׁא — גָּזְרִי בַּהּ רַבָּנַן, גִּיזָּה — לָא גָּזְרִי בַּהּ רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: said to When teaches is prohibited for labor, by rabbinic law. If so, even shearing it should be prohibited. said to him: With regard to labor, which weakens the Sages issued a decree with regard to shearing, the Sages did not issue a decree
llm_translation: He said to him: "When it is taught 'forbidden in labor' - it is from the Rabbis. If so, even with a shearing of wool it should also be prohibited!" He said to him: "Regarding labor which is somewhat concealed - the Rabbis decreed upon it, but regarding shearing - the Rabbis did not decree upon it."

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ אַבָּיֵי מֵרַב יוֹסֵף: הִיא שְׁלָמִים וּוְלָדָהּ חוּלִּין, וּשְׁחָטָהּ בִּפְנִים, מַהוּ? לְמַאן דְּאָמַר וַלְדֵי קָדָשִׁים בַּהֲוָיָיתָן הֵן קְדוֹשִׁין, מִי הָוֵי חוּלִּין בַּעֲזָרָה אוֹ לָא?
human_translation: Abaye posed a dilemma to Rav Yosef: it is a peace offering and its offspring is non-sacred, and he slaughtered inside what is according to the one who said offspring of sacrificial are sanctified when they come into being, are non-sacred in the courtyard, Or not
llm_translation: Abaye asked Rav Yosef: If she vowed to bring peace offerings and gave birth to a child, and it the child is mundane, and she slaughtered it inside the Temple courtyard, what is the law? According to the one who says that the offspring of consecrated animals are inherently holy, would it the offspring be considered mundane in the Temple courtyard or not?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִי קָרֵינָא בֵּיהּ ״כִּי יִרְחַק מִמְּךָ הַמָּקוֹם... וְזָבַחְתָּ״?
human_translation: said to Do we read “If the place be too far from you, then you shall slaughter to
llm_translation: He said to him: Who reads in it "When the place is far from you... and you shall sacrifice"?

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי מִינֵּיהּ אַבָּיֵי מֵרַב יוֹסֵף: הִיא חוּלִּין וּוְלָדָהּ שְׁלָמִים, וּשְׁחָטָהּ בְּחוּץ — מַהוּ? מִי מִחַיַּיב עֲלֵיהּ מִשּׁוּם שְׁחוּטֵי חוּץ, אוֹ לָא?
human_translation: Abaye posed dilemma to Rav Yosef: it, non-sacred, and its offspring is a peace offering, and he slaughtered it outside what is Is one liable for it due to slaughtering outside or not?
llm_translation: Abaye asked of Rava Yosef: "Its mother is a regular animal and its offspring is a peace offering, and it was slaughtered outside - what is the law? Who is liable for it, due to slaughtering it outside, or not?"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִי קָרֵינָא בֵּיהּ ״וֶהֱבִיאָם לַה׳״?
human_translation: said to Do we read “That they may bring them to the Lord” to
llm_translation: He said to him: Who reads in it "and brought them to the Lord"?

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: רָאוּי לְפֶתַח אֹהֶל מוֹעֵד חַיָּיבִין עָלָיו בַּחוּץ.
human_translation: another version said to one is liable for outside fit to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting,
llm_translation: The other sage said to him: "Fit for the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, one is liable for it outside."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין הַמְדוּמָּע מְדַמֵּעַ, אֶלָּא לְפִי חֶשְׁבּוֹן.
human_translation: mixture renders a mixture only according to calculation
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who is suspected of being a menstruant does not render others impure through contact, except according to calculation.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין הַמְחוּמָּץ מְחַמֵּץ אֶלָּא לְפִי חֶשְׁבּוֹן, וְאֵין הַמַּיִם שְׁאוּבִין פּוֹסְלִין אֶת הַמִּקְוֶה אֶלָּא לְפִי חֶשְׁבּוֹן.
human_translation: And that was leavened leavens only according to calculation And drawn water invalidates the ritual bath only according to calculation,
llm_translation: "And leaven only leavens according to calculation, and drawn water only invalidates the ritual bath according to calculation."

hebrew_text: וְאֵין מֵי חַטָּאת, עוֹשִׂין מֵי חַטָּאת אֶלָּא עִם מַתַּן אֵפֶר, וְאֵין בֵּית הַפְּרָס עוֹשִׂין בֵּית הַפְּרָס, וְאֵין תְּרוּמָה אַחַר תְּרוּמָה.
human_translation: And the water of purification becomes water of purification only with placement of ashes And beit haperas does not create beit haperas . And there is no teruma after teruma .
llm_translation: "And the waters of purification do not make the waters of purification except with the addition of ashes, and the house of separation does not make the house of separation, and there is no heave-offering after heave-offering."

hebrew_text: וְאֵין תְּמוּרָה עוֹשָׂה תְּמוּרָה, וְלֹא הַוָּלָד עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: הַוָּלָד עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: הֶקְדֵּשׁ עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה, וְאֵין הַוָּלָד עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה.
human_translation: And a substitute does not render a substitute; And the offspring does not render a substitute. Rabbi Yehuda says: The offspring renders a substitute. said to him: A consecrated renders a substitute, but the offspring does not render a substitute.
llm_translation: And exchange does not effect an exchange, and a fetus does not effect an exchange. Rabbi Yehuda says: A fetus effects an exchange. They said to him: Consecration effects an exchange, but a fetus does not effect an exchange.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַאן תַּנָּא? אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: דְּלָא כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
human_translation: Who is the tanna Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: not in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer.
llm_translation: The Talmudic text you provided translates into English as follows: Talmudic text: "Gemara, who is the Tanna? Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yohanan: Not like Rabbi Eliezer."

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: סְאָה שֶׁל תְּרוּמָה שֶׁנָּפְלָה לְפָחוֹת מִמֵּאָה חוּלִּין, וְנִדְמְעוּ, וְנָפַל מִן הַמְדוּמָּע לְמָקוֹם אַחֵר, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: מְדַמֵּעַ כִּתְרוּמָה וַדַּאי (שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹמֵר: סְאָה שֶׁנָּפְלָה הִיא שֶׁעָלְתָה).
human_translation: As we learned a se’a of teruma fell into less than one hundred non-sacred become mixture, and from the mixture fell into a different place Rabbi Eliezer says: renders it mixture as definite teruma
llm_translation: We have learned in a Mishnah: If a se'ah of terumah fell less than one hundred chulin, and it became mixed, and it fell from the pile to another place, Rabbi Eliezer says: It is considered as terumah and certainly (for I say: The se'ah that fell is the one that was lifted up).

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֵינָהּ מְדַמַּעַת אֶלָּא לְפִי חֶשְׁבּוֹן שֶׁבָּהּ.
human_translation: And the Rabbis say: renders mixture only according to calculation in
llm_translation: The Sages say: It does not cause tears except according to the calculation within it.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין הַמְחוּמָּץ מְחַמֵּץ כּוּ׳. אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַתְנִיתִין דְּלָא כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
human_translation: And that was leavened leavens only Rabbi Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The mishna is not in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer.
llm_translation: "And the leaven does not leaven the dough." Rabbi Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: The Mishnah is not in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer.

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: שְׂאוֹר שֶׁל חוּלִּין וְשֶׁל תְּרוּמָה שֶׁנָּפְלוּ לְתוֹךְ הָעִיסָּה, וְלֹא בָּזֶה כְּדֵי לְהַחְמִיץ, וְלֹא בָּזֶה כְּדֵי לְהַחְמִיץ, וְנִצְטָרְפוּ וְחִימְּצוּ. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אַחַר אַחֲרוֹן אֲנִי בָּא, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בֵּין שֶׁנָּפַל אִיסּוּר לְכַתְּחִילָּה וּבֵין שֶׁנָּפַל אִיסּוּר בַּסּוֹף, לְעוֹלָם אֵין אָסוּר עַד שֶׁיְּהֵא בּוֹ כְּדֵי לְהַחְמִיץ.
human_translation: As we learned non-sacred leaven and of teruma that fell into dough, this one not to cause to become leavened, and that one not to cause to become leavened, and they combined and caused to become leavened, Rabbi Eliezer says: I follow the final And the Rabbis say: Whether the forbidden item, fell first or the forbidden item fell last, it is prohibited only if there is enough of to cause to leaven.
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: If leaven of common dough and leaven of terumah fell into the dough, and one did not nullify it enough to cause it to ferment, and one did not nullify it enough to cause it to ferment, and they became mixed and fermented. Rabbi Eliezer says: "I come last," and the Sages say: Whether the forbidden leaven fell in at the beginning or at the end, it is never considered forbidden until there is enough of it to cause fermentation.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין הַמַּיִם שְׁאוּבִין פּוֹסְלִין אֶת הַמִּקְוֶה. מַאן תָּנָא? אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב הִיא, דִּתְנַן: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: מִקְוֶה שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ עֶשְׂרִים וְאַחַת סְאָה מֵי גְשָׁמִים, מְמַלֵּא בַּכָּתֵף תְּשַׁע עֶשְׂרֵה סְאָה, וּפוֹתְקָן לַמִּקְוֶה,
human_translation: And drawn water invalidates the ritual bath only Who is the tanna Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says Rabbi Yoḥanan says: It is Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, as we learned Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: a ritual bath contains twenty-one se’a of rainwater, One fills in the shoulder nineteen se’a , and lets flow [ ufotekan ] into the ritual bath,
llm_translation: The water of a cistern does not disqualify. Who is the Tanna? Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yohanan: It is Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov, as we learned: Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: A cistern that contains twenty-one se'ah of rainwater, one fills it with the shoulder nine se'ah, and he draws it into the cistern.

hebrew_text: וְהֵן טְהוֹרִין, שֶׁהַשְּׁאִיבָה מְטַהֶרֶת בִּרְבִיָּיה וּבְהַמְשָׁכָה.
human_translation: and are ritually pure. that drawn is purified by a majority and by flowing
llm_translation: And they are pure, for the suckling purifies with its saliva and with its drawing out.

hebrew_text: מִכְּלָל דְּרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי דְּבִרְבִיָּיה וּבְהַמְשָׁכָה לָא? אֶלָּא דְּכִי אֲתָא רָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שְׁאוּבָה שֶׁהִמְשִׁיכוּהָ כּוּלָּהּ — טְהוֹרָה. מַנִּי? לָא רַבָּנַן וְלָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר!
human_translation: by inference that the Rabbis hold that not by majority and by flowing But that Ravin when came Rabbi Yoḥanan said: in its entirety drawn that one made flow is pure. whose not the Rabbis, and not Rabbi Eliezer
llm_translation: From the premise of the sages, do they hold that in the case of a "Rabbi's daughter" and with regard to a "drawn-out" situation, it is not so? Rather, when Ravin came, Rabbi Yochanan said: A cistern that they have drawn out in its entirety — it is pure. Who is the authority? Not the sages, and not Rabbi Eliezer!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבָּה: לְפִי חֶשְׁבּוֹן כֵּלִים, וְיוֹסֵף בֶּן חוֹנִי הִיא.
